License: CC BY 4.0
arXiv:2410.03517v1 [cs.LG] 04 Oct 2024

Fine-Grained Expressive Power of Weisfeiler-Leman: A Homomorphism Counting Perspective

Junru Zhou1
zml72062@stu.pku.edu.cn&Muhan Zhang1
muhan@pku.edu.cn
Abstract

The ability of graph neural networks (GNNs) to count homomorphisms has recently been proposed as a practical and fine-grained measure of their expressive power. Although several existing works have investigated the homomorphism counting power of certain GNN families, a simple and unified framework for analyzing the problem is absent. In this paper, we first propose generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman (GFWL) algorithms as a flexible design basis for expressive GNNs, and then provide a theoretical framework to algorithmically determine the homomorphism counting power of an arbitrary class of GNN within the GFWL design space. As the considered design space is large enough to accommodate almost all known powerful GNNs, our result greatly extends all existing works, and may find its application in the automation of GNN model design.

1 Introduction

Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved remarkable success in the field of graph representation learning. However, since no deterministic polynomial-time algorithm for graph isomorphism testing has yet been found [2], none of the popular GNN models are universal approximators of graph functions even with sufficient number of parameters, according to Chen et al. [5]. This drawback of GNNs has been informally stated as the limited expressive power of GNNs.

In particular, Xu et al. [25] has proved that the expressive power of Message Passing Neural Networks (MPNNs), a widely adopted class of GNNs, is upper-bounded by that of 1-dimensional Weisfeiler-Leman (WL) algorithm, or 1-WL [24]. Following Xu et al. [25], numerous works have proposed more powerful GNNs based on higher-order WL algorithms as well as their variants [11, 12, 16, 19, 20, 22, 26, 29, 31]. Some of the works [19, 20, 22, 26, 29] even systematically compare the expressive power of those powerful GNNs, and establish expressiveness hierarchies among them. However, these comparisons usually fail to quantify the expressiveness gap between different methods, and provide little insight into what tasks a certain class of GNNs tend to excel at.

Recently, there are several works [17, 27] trying to characterize the expressive power of GNNs by considering their ability to perform homomorphism counting, namely, the power to determine the number of homomorphisms from a small query graph to the graph we are interested in. Earlier on, another line of works [6, 16, 31] has proposed to study GNN expressiveness by considering their substructure counting power, or the power to determine subgraph isomorphisms instead of homomorphisms. Both approaches can provide fine-grained knowledge about the expressive power of GNNs. As an example, the expressiveness gap between two families of GNNs can be made manifest by examining the substructures whose homomorphism (or isomorphism) counts that one of them can compute while the other cannot. Despite the similarity between those two perspectives, it is argued that homomorphism counting power is a better metric for expressiveness, due to reasons such as that homomorphism counts are known [7] to be a good basis upon which many other graph parameters (including subgraph isomorphism counts) can be computed, and that there is an exact equivalence [3, 8] between the ability to count homomorphisms for some certain classes of query graphs and the well-known Weisfeiler-Leman expressiveness hierarchy, while such equivalence does not exist for substructure counting.

As many popular GNNs are designed upon (and easily shown to be as expressive as) variants of WL algorithms, we may now confine our attention to the following question: what exactly query graphs whose homomorphisms can a specific variant of Weisfeiler-Leman algorithm count? While the terminologies in the above question are to be made clear later, we point out that answering the question is not easy. Even for the well-studied k𝑘kitalic_k-dimensional folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms (k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL) [4, 15, 18], determining their exact homomorphism counting power relies on the (not so intuitive) concept of tree decompositions [8]. Another work [27] closely follows [8], and extends its result to three other variants of WL algorithms using the language of nested ear decompositions. Despite those efforts, no answer to the above question has been given in the most general setting.

Main contributions.

We now summarize our main contributions as following:

  1. 1.

    We introduce the concept of generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman (GFWL) algorithms, which encompasses most existing variants of WL algorithms, including those proposed in the latest works such as [12, 31].

  2. 2.

    We derive the exact set of query graphs whose homomorphisms an instance of generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithm can count. In other words, we find that for any GFWL algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A-indistinguishability is always equivalent to identity in homomorphism counts from an appropriate set of graphs. Our results greatly extend those in [8, 27]. Our proof of Theorem 4.10 relies on the relationship between GFWL algorithms and two types of pebble games, namely Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé games and Cops-Robber games, which have been well-known tools to analyze k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL algorithms ever since [4, 10, 13, 23]. Our results show that these tools can be generalized to give a unified characterization of a much larger family of algorithms.

  3. 3.

    Our main result, Theorem 4.10, actually provides us with a meta-algorithm111We call it a meta-algorithm since it takes as input and evaluates another algorithm. to automate the procedure of determining the homomorphism counting power of any GFWL algorithm. We implement the meta-algorithm and validate its correctness by comparing its output with previous theoretical results in [1, 12, 16, 21, 26, 27, 31]. Our code is present at https://github.com/zml72062/pebble_game.

Limitations.

Although our proposed GFWL framework accommodates a number of existing powerful WL variants, such as k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL, local k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL [27] and δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ-DRFWL(2) [31], it still leaves some well-known variants out, like k𝑘kitalic_k-WL [19] or sparse k𝑘kitalic_k-WL [20]. Further, our current work focuses solely on homomorphism counting power, and does not discuss its connection with substructure counting power (the latter being more intuitive). Yet existing works [21, 27] have shown that at least for some specific WL variants, being able to count subgraph isomorphisms from a query graph H𝐻\bm{H}bold_italic_H is equivalent to being able to count homomorphisms from all homomorphism images of H𝐻\bm{H}bold_italic_H, indicating a deep connection exists between homomorphism counting and substructure (isomorphism) counting. While we conjecture that the above connection holds for general GFWL algorithms, we have difficulty proving it. Due to the aforementioned limitations, this paper serves as a preliminary work, and directions for future works are discussed in Section 5.

2 Notations and definitions

2.1 Basic notations

For any n∈ℕ∗𝑛superscriptℕn\in\mathbb{N}^{*}italic_n ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we denote [n]={1,2,…,n}delimited-[]𝑛12…𝑛[n]=\{1,2,\ldots,n\}[ italic_n ] = { 1 , 2 , … , italic_n }. Let 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G be the set of all simple, undirected graphs. For a graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G, we use 𝒱Gsubscript𝒱𝐺\mathcal{V}_{G}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ℰGsubscriptℰ𝐺\mathcal{E}_{G}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote its node set and edge set respectively. We call 𝐯=(v1,…,vk)∈𝒱Gk𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a k𝑘kitalic_k-tuple of nodes, or simply a k𝑘kitalic_k-tuple in G𝐺Gitalic_G. If C⊆𝒱G𝐶subscript𝒱𝐺C\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}italic_C ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we let G⁢[C]𝐺delimited-[]𝐶G[C]italic_G [ italic_C ] be the subgraph of G𝐺Gitalic_G induced by C𝐶Citalic_C.

Given G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and u,v∈𝒱G𝑢𝑣subscript𝒱𝐺u,v\in\mathcal{V}_{G}italic_u , italic_v ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we use d⁢(u,v)𝑑𝑢𝑣d(u,v)italic_d ( italic_u , italic_v ) to denote the shortest-path distance between u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v. The set of k𝑘kitalic_k-th hop neighbors of u∈𝒱G𝑢subscript𝒱𝐺u\in\mathcal{V}_{G}italic_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined as 𝒩k⁢(u)={v∈𝒱G:d⁢(u,v)=k}subscript𝒩𝑘𝑢conditional-set𝑣subscript𝒱𝐺𝑑𝑢𝑣𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k}(u)=\{v\in\mathcal{V}_{G}:d(u,v)=k\}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) = { italic_v ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_d ( italic_u , italic_v ) = italic_k }. We also denote 𝒩⩽k⁢(u)=⋃i=0k𝒩i⁢(u)subscript𝒩absent𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑘subscript𝒩𝑖𝑢\mathcal{N}_{\leqslant k}(u)=\bigcup_{i=0}^{k}\mathcal{N}_{i}(u)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩽ italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) and 𝒩⁢(u)=𝒩1⁢(u)𝒩𝑢subscript𝒩1𝑢\mathcal{N}(u)=\mathcal{N}_{1}(u)caligraphic_N ( italic_u ) = caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ).

2.2 Isomorphisms and homomorphisms

Let G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G, 𝐮=(u1,…,uk)∈𝒱Gk𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐯=(v1,…,vℓ)∈𝒱Hℓ𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻ℓ\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{\ell})\in\mathcal{V}_{H}^{\ell}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The two tuples 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u and 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v are said to have the same isomorphism type if (i) k=ℓ𝑘ℓk=\ellitalic_k = roman_ℓ, (ii) ∀i,j∈[k],ui=uj⇔vi=vj\forall i,j\in[k],u_{i}=u_{j}\Leftrightarrow v_{i}=v_{j}∀ italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_k ] , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⇔ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and (iii) ∀i,j∈[k],{ui,uj}∈ℰG⇔{vi,vj}∈ℰH\forall i,j\in[k],\{u_{i},u_{j}\}\in\mathcal{E}_{G}\Leftrightarrow\{v_{i},v_{j% }\}\in\mathcal{E}_{H}∀ italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_k ] , { italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⇔ { italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The above definition gives rise to an equivalence relation between two arbitrary tuples (which can lie in two different graphs and have different lengths). Therefore, we may use the symbol atp⁢(𝐮)atp𝐮\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{u})roman_atp ( bold_u ) to refer to the equivalence class induced by the above relation, to which 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u belongs; namely, atp⁢(𝐮)=atp⁢(𝐯)atp𝐮atp𝐯\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{u})=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v})roman_atp ( bold_u ) = roman_atp ( bold_v ) if and only if 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u and 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v have the same isomorphism type.

A homomorphism from graph G𝐺Gitalic_G to graph H𝐻Hitalic_H is a mapping h:𝒱G→𝒱H:ℎ→subscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝒱𝐻h:\mathcal{V}_{G}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}_{H}italic_h : caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for every {u,v}∈ℰG𝑢𝑣subscriptℰ𝐺\{u,v\}\in\mathcal{E}_{G}{ italic_u , italic_v } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have {h⁢(u),h⁢(v)}∈ℰHℎ𝑢ℎ𝑣subscriptℰ𝐻\{h(u),h(v)\}\in\mathcal{E}_{H}{ italic_h ( italic_u ) , italic_h ( italic_v ) } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. H𝐻Hitalic_H is called a homomorphism image of G𝐺Gitalic_G if there exists a homomorphism hℎhitalic_h from G𝐺Gitalic_G to H𝐻Hitalic_H satisfying (i) hℎhitalic_h is surjective, and (ii) for every u,v∈𝒱G𝑢𝑣subscript𝒱𝐺u,v\in\mathcal{V}_{G}italic_u , italic_v ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that {u,v}∉ℰG𝑢𝑣subscriptℰ𝐺\{u,v\}\notin\mathcal{E}_{G}{ italic_u , italic_v } ∉ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have {h⁢(u),h⁢(v)}∉ℰHℎ𝑢ℎ𝑣subscriptℰ𝐻\{h(u),h(v)\}\notin\mathcal{E}_{H}{ italic_h ( italic_u ) , italic_h ( italic_v ) } ∉ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We denote the set of all homomorphism images of G𝐺Gitalic_G (up to isomorphism) as Spasm⁢(G)Spasm𝐺\mathrm{Spasm}(G)roman_Spasm ( italic_G ).

Given two graphs F,G∈𝒢𝐹𝐺𝒢F,G\in\mathcal{G}italic_F , italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G, we use C⁢(F,G)𝐶𝐹𝐺C(F,G)italic_C ( italic_F , italic_G ) to denote the number of different subgraphs of G𝐺Gitalic_G that are isomorphic to F𝐹Fitalic_F, and use Hom⁢(F,G)Hom𝐹𝐺\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) to denote the number of different homomorphisms from F𝐹Fitalic_F to G𝐺Gitalic_G. Further given 𝐮=(u1,…,uk)∈𝒱Fk𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐹𝑘\mathbf{u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{F}^{k}bold_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐯=(v1,…,vk)∈𝒱Gk𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we use Hom⁢(F𝐮,G𝐯)Homsuperscript𝐹𝐮superscript𝐺𝐯\mathrm{Hom}(F^{\mathbf{u}},G^{\mathbf{v}})roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or Hom⁢(Fu1,…,uk,Gv1,…,vk)Homsuperscript𝐹subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝐺subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘\mathrm{Hom}(F^{u_{1},\ldots,u_{k}},G^{v_{1},\ldots,v_{k}})roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to denote the number of different homomorphisms hℎhitalic_h from F𝐹Fitalic_F to G𝐺Gitalic_G that satisfy h⁢(ui)=viℎsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖h(u_{i})=v_{i}italic_h ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for each i=1,…,k𝑖1…𝑘i=1,\ldots,kitalic_i = 1 , … , italic_k.

2.3 Invariant and equivariant sets

Let G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G be two graphs and f:𝒱G→𝒱H:𝑓→subscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝒱𝐻f:\mathcal{V}_{G}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}_{H}italic_f : caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a mapping. If 𝐯=(v1,…,vk)∈𝒱Gk𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we adopt the shorthand f⁢(𝐯)=(f⁢(v1),…,f⁢(vk))∈𝒱Hk𝑓𝐯𝑓subscript𝑣1…𝑓subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻𝑘f(\mathbf{v})=(f(v_{1}),\ldots,f(v_{k}))\in\mathcal{V}_{H}^{k}italic_f ( bold_v ) = ( italic_f ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , italic_f ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Similarly, if 𝒜⊆𝒱Gk𝒜superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathcal{A}\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}caligraphic_A ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a set of k𝑘kitalic_k-tuples in G𝐺Gitalic_G, we denote f⁢(𝒜)={f⁢(𝐯):𝐯∈𝒜}⊆𝒱Hk𝑓𝒜conditional-set𝑓𝐯𝐯𝒜superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻𝑘f(\mathcal{A})=\{f(\mathbf{v}):\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{A}\}\subseteq\mathcal{V}_% {H}^{k}italic_f ( caligraphic_A ) = { italic_f ( bold_v ) : bold_v ∈ caligraphic_A } ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We now define invariant and equivariant sets of k𝑘kitalic_k-tuples.

Definition 2.1 (Invariant set).

Let 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) be a function that maps every G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G to a set of k𝑘kitalic_k-tuples in G𝐺Gitalic_G. Namely, ∀G∈𝒢for-all𝐺𝒢\forall G\in\mathcal{G}∀ italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G, 𝒜⁢(G)⊆𝒱Gk𝒜𝐺superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathcal{A}(G)\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}caligraphic_A ( italic_G ) ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The function 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) is said to be 𝒌𝒌\bm{k}bold_italic_k-invariant if the following holds: for any graph H𝐻Hitalic_H isomorphic to G𝐺Gitalic_G, with f:𝒱G→𝒱H:𝑓→subscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝒱𝐻f:\mathcal{V}_{G}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}_{H}italic_f : caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being an isomorphism, we have f⁢(𝒜⁢(G))=𝒜⁢(H)𝑓𝒜𝐺𝒜𝐻f(\mathcal{A}(G))=\mathcal{A}(H)italic_f ( caligraphic_A ( italic_G ) ) = caligraphic_A ( italic_H ). If 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) is k𝑘kitalic_k-invariant, 𝒜⁢(G)⊆𝒱Gk𝒜𝐺superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathcal{A}(G)\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}caligraphic_A ( italic_G ) ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is said to be an invariant set of k𝑘\bm{k}bold_italic_k-tuples, or simply a 𝒌𝒌\bm{k}bold_italic_k-invariant set of G𝐺Gitalic_G, given any G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G.

For example, one can easily verify that {(u,v)∈𝒱G2:{u,v}∈ℰG}conditional-set𝑢𝑣superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺2𝑢𝑣subscriptℰ𝐺\{(u,v)\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{2}:\{u,v\}\in\mathcal{E}_{G}\}{ ( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : { italic_u , italic_v } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and {(u,v)∈𝒱G2:d⁢(u,v)⩽2}conditional-set𝑢𝑣superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺2𝑑𝑢𝑣2\{(u,v)\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{2}:d(u,v)\leqslant 2\}{ ( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_d ( italic_u , italic_v ) ⩽ 2 } are both 2-invariant sets of G𝐺Gitalic_G, given any G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G.

Definition 2.2 (Equivariant set).

Let 𝒜⁢(⋅,⋅)𝒜⋅⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) be a function that maps every G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G along with an ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ-tuple 𝐮∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to a set of k𝑘kitalic_k-tuples in G𝐺Gitalic_G. Namely, ∀G∈𝒢for-all𝐺𝒢\forall G\in\mathcal{G}∀ italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and 𝐮∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝒜⁢(G,𝐮)⊆𝒱Gk𝒜𝐺𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathcal{A}(G,\mathbf{u})\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}caligraphic_A ( italic_G , bold_u ) ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The function 𝒜⁢(⋅,⋅)𝒜⋅⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) is said to be (ℓ,𝒌)bold-ℓ𝒌\bm{(\ell,k)}bold_( bold_ℓ bold_, bold_italic_k bold_)-equivariant if the following holds: for any graph H𝐻Hitalic_H isomorphic to G𝐺Gitalic_G, with f:𝒱G→𝒱H:𝑓→subscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝒱𝐻f:\mathcal{V}_{G}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}_{H}italic_f : caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being an isomorphism, we have f⁢(𝒜⁢(G,𝐮))=𝒜⁢(H,f⁢(𝐮))𝑓𝒜𝐺𝐮𝒜𝐻𝑓𝐮f(\mathcal{A}(G,\mathbf{u}))=\mathcal{A}(H,f(\mathbf{u}))italic_f ( caligraphic_A ( italic_G , bold_u ) ) = caligraphic_A ( italic_H , italic_f ( bold_u ) ). If 𝒜⁢(⋅,⋅)𝒜⋅⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) is (ℓ,k)ℓ𝑘(\ell,k)( roman_ℓ , italic_k )-equivariant, 𝒜⁢(G,𝐮)⊆𝒱Gk𝒜𝐺𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathcal{A}(G,\mathbf{u})\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}caligraphic_A ( italic_G , bold_u ) ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is said to be an equivariant set of k𝑘\bm{k}bold_italic_k-tuples, or simply an (ℓ,𝒌)bold-ℓ𝒌\bm{(\ell,k)}bold_( bold_ℓ bold_, bold_italic_k bold_)-equivariant set of G𝐺Gitalic_G with respect to 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u, given any G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and 𝐮∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

For example, given any graph G𝐺Gitalic_G and (u,v)∈𝒱G2𝑢𝑣superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺2(u,v)\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{2}( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, {w:d⁢(u,w)⩽2⁢ and ⁢d⁢(w,v)⩽2}conditional-set𝑤𝑑𝑢𝑤2 and 𝑑𝑤𝑣2\{w:d(u,w)\leqslant 2\text{ and }d(w,v)\leqslant 2\}{ italic_w : italic_d ( italic_u , italic_w ) ⩽ 2 and italic_d ( italic_w , italic_v ) ⩽ 2 } is a (2,1)21(2,1)( 2 , 1 )-equivariant set of G𝐺Gitalic_G, with respect to (u,v)𝑢𝑣(u,v)( italic_u , italic_v ).

3 Related works

Comparisons with [8] and [27].

Prior to our work, Dell et al. [8] and Zhang et al. [27] have studied the homomorphism counting power of some variants of Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms. Dell et al. [8] shows that indistinguishability of two graphs G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H by k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL is equivalent to Hom⁢(F,G)=Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)=\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) = roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ) for all graphs F𝐹Fitalic_F with tree-width at most k𝑘kitalic_k. Zhang et al. [27] further extends the result of [8] to three other variants of WL algorithms, namely subgraph k𝑘kitalic_k-WL, local k𝑘kitalic_k-WL and local 2-FWL, using the language of nested ear decompositions. However, even [27] has not completely determined the homomorphism counting power of local k𝑘\bm{k}bold_italic_k-FWL, for the case of k>𝟐𝑘2\bm{k>2}bold_italic_k bold_> bold_2; [27] also leaves the question open whether the so-called homomorphism expressivity exists for any algorithms that adopt a color-refinement paradigm. Our work fills the gap in [27] regarding the homomorphism counting power of local k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL with k>2𝑘2k>2italic_k > 2, and provides an affirmative answer to the latter question for the case of GFWL algorithms.

Our work is also methodologically very different from [8] and [27]. The proof of our result no longer depends on concepts such as tree decompositions or nested ear decompositions, and is fully stated in the language of pebble games. Despite its relative conceptual simplicity, our result is much more general than those in [8] and [27], indicating that our approach (using pebble games) represents a better perspective to tackle the homomorphism counting problem.

Pebble games on graphs.

The Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé games, named after Ehrenfeucht [10] and Fraïssé [13], have been used to analyze the k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL algorithms in [4, 15]. More recent works [26, 28] generalize the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé games to provide game-theoretic characterizations for other variants of WL algorithms.

The Cops-Robber games, initially appearing as an instance of graph searching games, are intensively studied by Seymour and Thomas [23]. The original version of the game includes k𝑘kitalic_k Cops trying to trap a Robber on a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G, where Robber is only capable of moving along the edges to a Cop-free node. The central result of [23] is a vital property of the game: if Cops can guarantee to win the game, they can win monotonically, meaning that they can ensure Robber never return to a node they have previously expelled Robber from. One corollary of the property is that Cops can win the Cops-Robber game on G𝐺Gitalic_G if and only if k⩾tree-width⁢(G)+1𝑘tree-width𝐺1k\geqslant\text{tree-width}(G)+1italic_k ⩾ tree-width ( italic_G ) + 1. The standard textbook [9] on graph theory provides a simpler proof for the latter result. Several recent works [21, 26, 27] have revived the Cops-Robber games by relating them to Fürer graphs [4], which are standard testers for expressive power. However, none of the existing works have directly examined the relationship between Cops-Robber games and the homomorphism counting power of WL algorithms. As is presented in our main theorem (Theorem 4.10), such a relationship is surprisingly simple and beautiful.

We also remark that Appendix A.1 of [27] provides a detailed review of existing approaches to the design of expressive GNNs, which is closely related to our work.

4 Results

4.1 Generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms

In this subsection, we present the definition of generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms, which extend (k,t)𝑘𝑡(k,t)( italic_k , italic_t )-FWL+ defined in [12]. Before embarking on the detailed discussion, we introduce a few notations.

Definition 4.1 (Concatenation).

Let 𝐯=(v1,…,vk)∈𝒱Gk𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐮=(u1,…,uℓ)∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{\ell})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The (k+ℓ)𝑘ℓ(k+\ell)( italic_k + roman_ℓ )-tuple (v1,…,vk,u1,…,uℓ)∈𝒱Gk+ℓsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘ℓ(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k},u_{1},\ldots,u_{\ell})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k+\ell}( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called the concatenation of 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v and 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u, denoted as (𝐯,𝐮)𝐯𝐮(\mathbf{v},\mathbf{u})( bold_v , bold_u ).

The following definition follows that of neighborhood tuples introduced in [12], but is slightly different.

Definition 4.2 (Replacement).

Let 𝐯=(v1,…,vk)∈𝒱Gk𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐮=(u1,…,uℓ)∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{\ell})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Denote vk+1=u1,…,vk+ℓ=uℓformulae-sequencesubscript𝑣𝑘1subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑣𝑘ℓsubscript𝑢ℓv_{k+1}=u_{1},\ldots,v_{k+\ell}=u_{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For any k𝑘kitalic_k indices r1,…,rk∈[k+ℓ]subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑘delimited-[]𝑘ℓr_{1},\ldots,r_{k}\in[k+\ell]italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_k + roman_ℓ ] with r1<r2<⋯<rksubscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2⋯subscript𝑟𝑘r_{1}<r_{2}<\cdots<r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ⋯ < italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the k𝑘kitalic_k-tuple

REPLACE⁢(𝐯,𝐮;r1,…,rk)=(vr1,…,vrk)∈𝒱GkREPLACE𝐯𝐮subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑘subscript𝑣subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑣subscript𝑟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\displaystyle\mathrm{REPLACE}(\mathbf{v},\mathbf{u};r_{1},\ldots,r_{k})=(v_{r_% {1}},\ldots,v_{r_{k}})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}roman_REPLACE ( bold_v , bold_u ; italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (1)

is called a replacement of 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v by 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u.

The most basic operation of generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms is aggregation, which we describe below.

Definition 4.3.

Let 𝒜⊆𝒱Gk𝒜superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathcal{A}\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}caligraphic_A ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ℓ<kℓ𝑘\ell<kroman_ℓ < italic_k. For any 𝐮=(u1,…,uℓ)∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{\ell})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, denote

𝒜\𝐮={(w1,…,wk−ℓ)∈𝒱Gk−ℓ:(u1,…,uℓ,w1,…,wk−ℓ)∈𝒜}.\𝒜𝐮conditional-setsubscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑘ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘ℓsubscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢ℓsubscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑘ℓ𝒜\displaystyle\mathcal{A}\backslash\mathbf{u}=\{(w_{1},\ldots,w_{k-\ell})\in% \mathcal{V}_{G}^{k-\ell}:(u_{1},\ldots,u_{\ell},w_{1},\ldots,w_{k-\ell})\in% \mathcal{A}\}.caligraphic_A \ bold_u = { ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_A } . (2)

Let W⁢(⋅)𝑊⋅W(\cdot)italic_W ( ⋅ ) be a function defined on 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A. Define 𝒜′⊆𝒱Gℓsuperscript𝒜′superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathcal{A}^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a new function W′⁢(⋅)superscript𝑊′⋅W^{\prime}(\cdot)italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) on 𝒜′superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}^{\prime}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as following:

𝒜′superscript𝒜′\displaystyle\mathcal{A}^{\prime}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ={𝐮∈𝒱Gℓ:𝒜\𝐮≠∅},absentconditional-set𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\𝒜𝐮\displaystyle=\{\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}:\mathcal{A}\backslash% \mathbf{u}\neq\varnothing\},= { bold_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : caligraphic_A \ bold_u ≠ ∅ } , (3)
W′⁢(𝐮)superscript𝑊′𝐮\displaystyle W^{\prime}(\mathbf{u})italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_u ) =ℋ⁢({{W⁢(𝐯):𝐯=(𝐮,𝐰), for some ⁢𝐰∈𝒜\𝐮}}),∀𝐮∈𝒜′,formulae-sequenceabsentℋconditional-set𝑊𝐯formulae-sequence𝐯𝐮𝐰 for some 𝐰\𝒜𝐮for-all𝐮superscript𝒜′\displaystyle=\mathcal{H}\left(\{\!\!\{W(\mathbf{v}):\mathbf{v}=(\mathbf{u},% \mathbf{w}),\text{ for some }\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{A}\backslash\mathbf{u}\}\!% \!\}\right),\quad\forall\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{A}^{\prime},= caligraphic_H ( { { italic_W ( bold_v ) : bold_v = ( bold_u , bold_w ) , for some bold_w ∈ caligraphic_A \ bold_u } } ) , ∀ bold_u ∈ caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (4)

where ℋ⁢(⋅)ℋ⋅\mathcal{H}(\cdot)caligraphic_H ( ⋅ ) is an injective hashing function operating on multisets. The above procedure producing 𝒜′superscript𝒜′\mathcal{A}^{\prime}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and W′⁢(⋅)superscript𝑊′⋅W^{\prime}(\cdot)italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) is called an aggregation operation on 𝒜𝒜\bm{\mathcal{A}}bold_caligraphic_A and W⁢(⋅)𝑊bold-⋅\bm{W(\cdot)}bold_italic_W bold_( bold_⋅ bold_). We adopt the notations

𝒜′superscript𝒜′\displaystyle\mathcal{A^{\prime}}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =AGGRℓℋ⁢(𝒜),absentsuperscriptsubscriptAGGRℓℋ𝒜\displaystyle=\mathrm{AGGR}_{\ell}^{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{A}),= roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ) , (5)
W′⁢(𝐮)superscript𝑊′𝐮\displaystyle W^{\prime}(\mathbf{u})italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_u ) =AGGRℓℋ⁢(𝐮;W⁢(⋅),𝒜),∀𝐮∈𝒜′formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscriptAGGRℓℋ𝐮𝑊⋅𝒜for-all𝐮superscript𝒜′\displaystyle=\mathrm{AGGR}_{\ell}^{\mathcal{H}}(\mathbf{u};W(\cdot),\mathcal{% A}),\quad\forall\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{A}^{\prime}= roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_u ; italic_W ( ⋅ ) , caligraphic_A ) , ∀ bold_u ∈ caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (6)

as mere shorthands for equations (3) and (4). We often omit the superscript ℋℋ\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H in AGGRℓℋsuperscriptsubscriptAGGRℓℋ\mathrm{AGGR}_{\ell}^{\mathcal{H}}roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if we are not interested in the specific choice of ℋ⁢(⋅)ℋ⋅\mathcal{H}(\cdot)caligraphic_H ( ⋅ ). We also note that when ℓ=0ℓ0\ell=0roman_ℓ = 0, equation (4) yields a single value W′=ℋ⁢({{W⁢(𝐯):𝐯∈𝒜}})superscript𝑊′ℋconditional-set𝑊𝐯𝐯𝒜W^{\prime}=\mathcal{H}\left(\{\!\!\{W(\mathbf{v}):\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{A}\}\!% \!\}\right)italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_H ( { { italic_W ( bold_v ) : bold_v ∈ caligraphic_A } } ) with no 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u dependence.

We are now ready to give a formal description of generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman (GFWL) algorithms. Any specific instance of the algorithm depends on several “hyperparameters”, which we list below.

Assumption 4.4.

Let k,t∈ℕ∗𝑘𝑡superscriptℕk,t\in\mathbb{N}^{*}italic_k , italic_t ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 0=i0<i1<i2<⋯<iN=k0subscript𝑖0subscript𝑖1subscript𝑖2⋯subscript𝑖𝑁𝑘0=i_{0}<i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots<i_{N}=k0 = italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ⋯ < italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k and 0=j0<j1<j2<⋯<jM=t0subscript𝑗0subscript𝑗1subscript𝑗2⋯subscript𝑗𝑀𝑡0=j_{0}<j_{1}<j_{2}<\cdots<j_{M}=t0 = italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ⋯ < italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_t. Further let ℛ⁢(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot)caligraphic_R ( ⋅ ) be a k𝑘kitalic_k-invariant function, and let ℱ⁢(⋅,⋅)ℱ⋅⋅\mathcal{F}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_F ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) be a (k,t)𝑘𝑡(k,t)( italic_k , italic_t )-equivariant function.

Definition 4.5 (Generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms).

The algorithm computes W⁢(G)𝑊𝐺W(G)italic_W ( italic_G ) for any graph G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G by executing the following steps:

  • •

    Initialization. Assign an initial color W(0)⁢(𝐯)superscript𝑊0𝐯W^{(0)}(\mathbf{v})italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ) to every 𝐯∈ℛ⁢(G)𝐯ℛ𝐺\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ). We require that

    W(0)⁢(𝐯)=Φ⁢(atp⁢(𝐯)),superscript𝑊0𝐯Φatp𝐯\displaystyle W^{(0)}(\mathbf{v})=\Phi(\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v})),italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ) = roman_Φ ( roman_atp ( bold_v ) ) , (7)

    where Φ⁢(⋅)Φ⋅\Phi(\cdot)roman_Φ ( ⋅ ) is an injective function.

  • •

    Update. An update step includes message computation and aggregation. In the following, we let W(T)⁢(𝐯)superscript𝑊𝑇𝐯W^{(T)}(\mathbf{v})italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ) be the color of 𝐯∈ℛ⁢(G)𝐯ℛ𝐺\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ) at the T𝑇Titalic_T-th iteration, for T=0,1,…𝑇01…T=0,1,\ldotsitalic_T = 0 , 1 , ….

    • ∘\circ∘

      Message computation. For each 𝐯∈ℛ⁢(G)𝐯ℛ𝐺\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ) and 𝐮∈ℱ⁢(G,𝐯)𝐮ℱ𝐺𝐯\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{F}(G,\mathbf{v})bold_u ∈ caligraphic_F ( italic_G , bold_v ), there are C=(k+tk)𝐶binomial𝑘𝑡𝑘C=\binom{k+t}{k}italic_C = ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k + italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ) different replacements of 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v by 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u, denoted as

      𝐯c⁢(𝐮)=REPLACE⁢(𝐯,𝐮;r1(c),…,rk(c)),c=1,…,C.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐯𝑐𝐮REPLACE𝐯𝐮superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑐…superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑐𝑐1…𝐶\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{c}(\mathbf{u})=\mathrm{REPLACE}(\mathbf{v},\mathbf{u}% ;r_{1}^{(c)},\ldots,r_{k}^{(c)}),\quad c=1,\ldots,C.bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) = roman_REPLACE ( bold_v , bold_u ; italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_c = 1 , … , italic_C . (8)

      We sort {𝐯c⁢(𝐮):c∈[C]}conditional-setsubscript𝐯𝑐𝐮𝑐delimited-[]𝐶\{\mathbf{v}_{c}(\mathbf{u}):c\in[C]\}{ bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) : italic_c ∈ [ italic_C ] } according to the lexicographic order of (r1(c),…,rk(c))superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑐…superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑐(r_{1}^{(c)},\ldots,r_{k}^{(c)})( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Compute the message from 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u to 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v as following:222We implicitly assume that each 𝐯c⁢(𝐮)∈ℛ⁢(G)subscript𝐯𝑐𝐮ℛ𝐺\mathbf{v}_{c}(\mathbf{u})\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ), for any 𝐯∈ℛ⁢(G)𝐯ℛ𝐺\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ), 𝐮∈ℱ⁢(G,𝐯)𝐮ℱ𝐺𝐯\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{F}(G,\mathbf{v})bold_u ∈ caligraphic_F ( italic_G , bold_v ) and c∈[C]𝑐delimited-[]𝐶c\in\left[C\right]italic_c ∈ [ italic_C ].

      MSG(T)⁢(𝐮;𝐯)=(W(T)⁢(𝐯1⁢(𝐮)),…,W(T)⁢(𝐯C⁢(𝐮))).superscriptMSG𝑇𝐮𝐯superscript𝑊𝑇subscript𝐯1𝐮…superscript𝑊𝑇subscript𝐯𝐶𝐮\displaystyle\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}(\mathbf{u};\mathbf{v})=\left(W^{(T)}(\mathbf{v% }_{1}(\mathbf{u})),\ldots,W^{(T)}(\mathbf{v}_{C}(\mathbf{u}))\right).roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_u ; bold_v ) = ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) ) , … , italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) ) ) . (9)

      Thus, MSG(T)⁢(⋅;𝐯)superscriptMSG𝑇⋅𝐯\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}(\cdot;\mathbf{v})roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ; bold_v ) is a color-vector-valued function on ℱ⁢(G,𝐯)ℱ𝐺𝐯\mathcal{F}(G,\mathbf{v})caligraphic_F ( italic_G , bold_v ).

    • ∘\circ∘

      Aggregation. For every 𝐯∈ℛ⁢(G)𝐯ℛ𝐺\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ), perform M𝑀Mitalic_M consecutive aggregation operations on ℱ⁢(G,𝐯)ℱ𝐺𝐯\mathcal{F}(G,\mathbf{v})caligraphic_F ( italic_G , bold_v ) and MSG(T)⁢(⋅;𝐯)superscriptMSG𝑇⋅𝐯\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}(\cdot;\mathbf{v})roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ; bold_v ): setting ℱM⁢(G,𝐯)=ℱ⁢(G,𝐯)subscriptℱ𝑀𝐺𝐯ℱ𝐺𝐯\mathcal{F}_{M}(G,\mathbf{v})=\mathcal{F}(G,\mathbf{v})caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_v ) = caligraphic_F ( italic_G , bold_v ) and MSGM(T)⁢(⋅;𝐯)=MSG(T)⁢(⋅;𝐯)subscriptsuperscriptMSG𝑇𝑀⋅𝐯superscriptMSG𝑇⋅𝐯\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}_{M}(\cdot;\mathbf{v})=\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}(\cdot;\mathbf{v})roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ; bold_v ) = roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ; bold_v ), we let

      ℱm−1⁢(G,𝐯)subscriptℱ𝑚1𝐺𝐯\displaystyle\mathcal{F}_{m-1}(G,\mathbf{v})caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_v ) =AGGRjm−1⁢(ℱm⁢(G,𝐯))⊆𝒱Gjm−1,absentsubscriptAGGRsubscript𝑗𝑚1subscriptℱ𝑚𝐺𝐯superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝑗𝑚1\displaystyle=\mathrm{AGGR}_{j_{m-1}}(\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{v}))\subseteq% \mathcal{V}_{G}^{j_{m-1}},= roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_v ) ) ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (10)
      MSGm−1(T)⁢(𝐮;𝐯)subscriptsuperscriptMSG𝑇𝑚1𝐮𝐯\displaystyle\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}_{m-1}(\mathbf{u};\mathbf{v})roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ; bold_v ) =AGGRjm−1⁢(𝐮;MSGm(T)⁢(⋅;𝐯),ℱm⁢(G,𝐯)),𝐮∈ℱm−1⁢(G,𝐯),formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptAGGRsubscript𝑗𝑚1𝐮subscriptsuperscriptMSG𝑇𝑚⋅𝐯subscriptℱ𝑚𝐺𝐯𝐮subscriptℱ𝑚1𝐺𝐯\displaystyle=\mathrm{AGGR}_{j_{m-1}}(\mathbf{u};\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}_{m}(\cdot;% \mathbf{v}),\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{v})),\quad\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{F}_{m-1}% (G,\mathbf{v}),= roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ; roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ; bold_v ) , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_v ) ) , bold_u ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_v ) , (11)

      for m=M,M−1,…,1𝑚𝑀𝑀1…1m=M,M-1,\ldots,1italic_m = italic_M , italic_M - 1 , … , 1.333For aggregation operations at different steps (i.e., AGGRjm−1subscriptAGGRsubscript𝑗𝑚1\mathrm{AGGR}_{j_{m-1}}roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with different m𝑚mitalic_m values), different ℋ⁢(⋅)ℋ⋅\mathcal{H}(\cdot)caligraphic_H ( ⋅ ) functions can be used. A similar remark applies to the pooling step. Since j0=0subscript𝑗00j_{0}=0italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the last aggregation operation yields MSG0(T)⁢(𝐯)subscriptsuperscriptMSG𝑇0𝐯\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}_{0}(\mathbf{v})roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v ) which is independent of 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u. We let

      W(T+1)⁢(𝐯)=MSG0(T)⁢(𝐯).superscript𝑊𝑇1𝐯subscriptsuperscriptMSG𝑇0𝐯\displaystyle W^{(T+1)}(\mathbf{v})=\mathrm{MSG}^{(T)}_{0}(\mathbf{v}).italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ) = roman_MSG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v ) . (12)
  • •

    Pooling. Repeat the update step until the colors W(T)⁢(𝐯),𝐯∈ℛ⁢(G)superscript𝑊𝑇𝐯𝐯ℛ𝐺W^{(T)}(\mathbf{v}),\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}(G)italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ) , bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ) go stable. Denote the stable coloring of 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v as W(∞)⁢(𝐯)superscript𝑊𝐯W^{(\infty)}(\mathbf{v})italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ). Perform N𝑁Nitalic_N consecutive aggregation operations on ℛ⁢(G)ℛ𝐺\mathcal{R}(G)caligraphic_R ( italic_G ) and W(∞)⁢(⋅)superscript𝑊⋅W^{(\infty)}(\cdot)italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ): setting ℛN⁢(G)=ℛ⁢(G)subscriptℛ𝑁𝐺ℛ𝐺\mathcal{R}_{N}(G)=\mathcal{R}(G)caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) = caligraphic_R ( italic_G ) and WN(∞)⁢(⋅)=W(∞)⁢(⋅)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑁⋅superscript𝑊⋅W_{N}^{(\infty)}(\cdot)=W^{(\infty)}(\cdot)italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ), we let

    ℛn−1⁢(G)subscriptℛ𝑛1𝐺\displaystyle\mathcal{R}_{n-1}(G)caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) =AGGRin−1⁢(ℛn⁢(G))⊆𝒱Gin−1,absentsubscriptAGGRsubscript𝑖𝑛1subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝑖𝑛1\displaystyle=\mathrm{AGGR}_{i_{n-1}}(\mathcal{R}_{n}(G))\subseteq\mathcal{V}_% {G}^{i_{n-1}},= roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) ) ⊆ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (13)
    Wn−1(∞)⁢(𝐯)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑛1𝐯\displaystyle W_{n-1}^{(\infty)}(\mathbf{v})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_v ) =AGGRin−1⁢(𝐯;Wn(∞)⁢(⋅),ℛn⁢(G)),𝐯∈ℛn−1⁢(G),formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptAGGRsubscript𝑖𝑛1𝐯superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑛⋅subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺𝐯subscriptℛ𝑛1𝐺\displaystyle=\mathrm{AGGR}_{i_{n-1}}(\mathbf{v};W_{n}^{(\infty)}(\cdot),% \mathcal{R}_{n}(G)),\quad\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{R}_{n-1}(G),= roman_AGGR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v ; italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) ) , bold_v ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) , (14)

    for n=N,N−1,…,1𝑛𝑁𝑁1…1n=N,N-1,\ldots,1italic_n = italic_N , italic_N - 1 , … , 1. Since i0=0subscript𝑖00i_{0}=0italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, we eventually get a single color W0(∞)subscriptsuperscript𝑊0W^{(\infty)}_{0}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT independent of 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v. We let W⁢(G)=W0(∞)𝑊𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝑊0W(G)=W^{(\infty)}_{0}italic_W ( italic_G ) = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∞ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

One can see that if we set N=k,M=tformulae-sequence𝑁𝑘𝑀𝑡N=k,M=titalic_N = italic_k , italic_M = italic_t and (i0,i1,…,iN)=(0,1,…,k),(j0,j1,…,jM)=(0,1,…,t)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖0subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑁01…𝑘subscript𝑗0subscript𝑗1…subscript𝑗𝑀01…𝑡(i_{0},i_{1},\ldots,i_{N})=(0,1,\ldots,k),(j_{0},j_{1},\ldots,j_{M})=(0,1,% \ldots,t)( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( 0 , 1 , … , italic_k ) , ( italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( 0 , 1 , … , italic_t ) in Assumption 4.4, our Definition 4.5 gives a (k,t)𝑘𝑡(k,t)( italic_k , italic_t )-FWL+ instance as defined in [12]. We point out that many other variants of WL algorithms [26, 27, 31] can be unified into the GFWL framework, as is shown in Appendix A.

4.2 Pebble games

In this paper, we consider two types of pebble games: the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game [4, 8, 10, 13, 15] and the Cops-Robber game [21, 23, 26, 27]. We assume that Assumption 4.4 holds throughout this subsection.

Definition 4.6 (Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game).

Assume there are a total of (k+t)𝑘𝑡(k+t)( italic_k + italic_t ) pairs of pebbles (p1,q1),…,(pk+t,(p_{1},q_{1}),\ldots,(p_{k+t},( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , qk+t)q_{k+t})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), all initially off the table. We call the pebbles (p1,q1),…,(pk,qk)subscript𝑝1subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘(p_{1},q_{1}),\ldots,(p_{k},q_{k})( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , … , ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) main pebbles, and the pebbles (pk+1,qk+1),subscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝑞𝑘1(p_{k+1},q_{k+1}),( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , …,(pk+t,qk+t)…subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡\ldots,(p_{k+t},q_{k+t})… , ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) auxiliary pebbles.

Let G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G be two graphs placed on the table. Two players (named Spoiler and Duplicator respectively)444We will use masculine pronouns for Spoiler, and feminine pronouns for Duplicator. play the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H as following:

  • •

    The two players first play an initialization round with N𝑁Nitalic_N putting moves, numbered by n=1,…,N𝑛1…𝑁n=1,\ldots,Nitalic_n = 1 , … , italic_N. The game rule guarantees that before the n𝑛nitalic_n-th putting move begins, the pebbles p1,…,pin−1subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛1p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{n-1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy an in−1subscript𝑖𝑛1i_{n-1}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple 𝐮n−1(0)superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of G𝐺Gitalic_G, while the pebbles q1,…,qin−1subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞subscript𝑖𝑛1q_{1},\ldots,q_{i_{n-1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy an in−1subscript𝑖𝑛1i_{n-1}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple 𝐯n−1(0)superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛10\mathbf{v}_{n-1}^{(0)}bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of H𝐻Hitalic_H.555Before the first (n=1𝑛1n=1italic_n = 1) putting move, there should be no pebbles on either graph, since i0=0subscript𝑖00i_{0}=0italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. The n𝑛nitalic_n-th putting move includes the following steps:

    1. 1.

      Duplicator chooses a bijection f:ℛn⁢(G)\𝐮n−1(0)→ℛn⁢(H)\𝐯n−1(0):𝑓→\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛1\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝐯0𝑛1f:\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)\backslash\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n-1}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}_{n}% (H)\backslash\mathbf{v}^{(0)}_{n-1}italic_f : caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ) \ bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ℛn⁢(⋅)subscriptℛ𝑛⋅\mathcal{R}_{n}(\cdot)caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) is defined in equation (13).

  • •

    After the initialization round, the two players repeatedly play the update round, each with M𝑀Mitalic_M putting moves (numbered by m=1,…,M𝑚1…𝑀m=1,\ldots,Mitalic_m = 1 , … , italic_M) and one removing move.

    Throughout the M𝑀Mitalic_M putting moves of the T𝑇Titalic_T-th update round, the main pebbles p1,…,pksubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘p_{1},\ldots,p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and q1,…,qksubscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑘q_{1},\ldots,q_{k}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stay unmoved at 𝐮N(T−1)subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐯N(T−1)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑇1𝑁\mathbf{v}^{(T-1)}_{N}bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. The game rule guarantees that before the m𝑚mitalic_m-th putting move begins, the auxiliary pebbles pk+1,…,pk+jm−1subscript𝑝𝑘1…subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚1p_{k+1},\ldots,p_{k+j_{m-1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy a jm−1subscript𝑗𝑚1j_{m-1}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple 𝐮m−1′⁣(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of G𝐺Gitalic_G, while qk+1,…,qk+jm−1subscript𝑞𝑘1…subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚1q_{k+1},\ldots,q_{k+j_{m-1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy a jm−1subscript𝑗𝑚1j_{m-1}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple 𝐯m−1′⁣(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑇𝑚1\mathbf{v}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1}bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of H𝐻Hitalic_H. The m𝑚mitalic_m-th putting move includes the following steps:

    1. 1.

      Duplicator chooses a bijection f:ℱm⁢(G,𝐮N(T−1))\𝐮m−1′⁣(T)→ℱm⁢(H,𝐯N(T−1))\𝐯m−1′⁣(T):𝑓→\subscriptℱ𝑚𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1\subscriptℱ𝑚𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑇1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑇𝑚1f:\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N})\backslash\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m% -1}\rightarrow\mathcal{F}_{m}(H,\mathbf{v}^{(T-1)}_{N})\backslash\mathbf{v}^{% \prime(T)}_{m-1}italic_f : caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H , bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) \ bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ℱm⁢(⋅,⋅)subscriptℱ𝑚⋅⋅\mathcal{F}_{m}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) is defined in equation (10).

    2. 2.

      Spoiler chooses Δ⁢𝐮m′⁣(T)∈ℱm⁢(G,𝐮N(T−1))\𝐮m−1′⁣(T)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚\subscriptℱ𝑚𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1\Delta\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m}\in\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N})% \backslash\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let Δ⁢𝐯m′⁣(T)=f⁢(Δ⁢𝐮m′⁣(T))Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑇𝑚𝑓Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚\Delta\mathbf{v}^{\prime(T)}_{m}=f(\Delta\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m})roman_Δ bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).     After the m𝑚mitalic_m-th putting move, the pebbles pk+1,…,pk+jmsubscript𝑝𝑘1…subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚p_{k+1},\ldots,p_{k+j_{m}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy 𝐮m′⁣(T)=(𝐮m−1′⁣(T),Δ⁢𝐮m′⁣(T))∈ℱm⁢(G,𝐮N(T−1))subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚subscriptℱ𝑚𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m}=(\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1},\Delta\mathbf{u}^{% \prime(T)}_{m})\in\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N})bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m -
