1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

    After all M𝑀Mitalic_M putting moves (now we have p1,…,pk+tsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{1},\ldots,p_{k+t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and q1,…,qk+tsubscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{1},\ldots,q_{k+t}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT located on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H perspectively), the removing move goes as follows. Spoiler arbitrarily chooses k𝑘kitalic_k indices r1,…,rk∈[k+t]subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑘delimited-[]𝑘𝑡r_{1},\ldots,r_{k}\in[k+t]italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_k + italic_t ] with r1<⋯<rksubscript𝑟1⋯subscript𝑟𝑘r_{1}<\cdots<r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ⋯ < italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. He then removes all pebbles on G𝐺Gitalic_G other than pr1,…,prksubscript𝑝subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑟𝑘p_{r_{1}},\ldots,p_{r_{k}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and relabels the pebbles such that prssubscript𝑝subscript𝑟𝑠p_{r_{s}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes pssubscript𝑝𝑠p_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for s=1,…,k𝑠1…𝑘s=1,\ldots,kitalic_s = 1 , … , italic_k. Accordingly, Spoiler also removes all pebbles on H𝐻Hitalic_H other than qr1,…,qrksubscript𝑞subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑞subscript𝑟𝑘q_{r_{1}},\ldots,q_{r_{k}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and relabels qrssubscript𝑞subscript𝑟𝑠q_{r_{s}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to qssubscript𝑞𝑠q_{s}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for s=1,…,k𝑠1…𝑘s=1,\ldots,kitalic_s = 1 , … , italic_k. Finally, he lets 𝐮N(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇𝑁\mathbf{u}^{(T)}_{N}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐯N(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐯𝑇𝑁\mathbf{v}^{(T)}_{N}bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the k𝑘kitalic_k-tuples occupied by (pebbles now labeled as) p1,…,pksubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘p_{1},\ldots,p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and q1,…,qksubscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞𝑘q_{1},\ldots,q_{k}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively.

Spoiler wins the game if either of the following happens: (i) Duplicator fails to find a bijection f𝑓fitalic_f in a putting move; (ii) when a (putting or removing) move ends, atp⁢(𝐮)≠atp⁢(𝐯)atp𝐮atp𝐯\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{u})\neq\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v})roman_atp ( bold_u ) ≠ roman_atp ( bold_v ), where 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u and 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v are the tuples of nodes occupied by pebbles on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H (ordered by the indices of pebbles) at the end of the move. Duplicator wins the game if Spoiler cannot win the game after any number of moves.

Definition 4.7 (Cops-Robber game).

Assume there are a total of (k+t)𝑘𝑡(k+t)( italic_k + italic_t ) pebbles p1,…,pk+tsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{1},\ldots,p_{k+t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all initially off the table. We call the pebbles p1,…,pksubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘p_{1},\ldots,p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT main pebbles, and the pebbles pk+1,…,pk+tsubscript𝑝𝑘1…subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k+1},\ldots,p_{k+t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT auxiliary pebbles.

Let G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G be a graph placed on the table. Two players (named Cops and Robber respectively)666We will use plural verbs and pronouns for Cops, although “Cops” is indeed an individual player. For Robber, we will use masculine pronouns. play the Cops-Robber game on G𝐺Gitalic_G as following:

  • •

    Throughout the game, Robber maintains a subset C𝐶Citalic_C of 𝒱Gsubscript𝒱𝐺\mathcal{V}_{G}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that G⁢[C]𝐺delimited-[]𝐶G[C]italic_G [ italic_C ] is connected. Before the game starts, Robber chooses C𝐶Citalic_C as a connected component777A connected component of G𝐺Gitalic_G is an equivalence class on 𝒱Gsubscript𝒱𝐺\mathcal{V}_{G}caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under the reachability relation. of G𝐺Gitalic_G.

  • •

    The two players first play an initialization round with N𝑁Nitalic_N guarding moves, numbered by n=1,…,N𝑛1…𝑁n=1,\ldots,Nitalic_n = 1 , … , italic_N. The game rule guarantees that before the n𝑛nitalic_n-th guarding move begins, the pebbles p1,…,pin−1subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛1p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{n-1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy an in−1subscript𝑖𝑛1i_{n-1}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple 𝐮n−1(0)subscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛1\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n-1}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of G𝐺Gitalic_G. The n𝑛nitalic_n-th guarding move goes as follows:

    1. 1.

      Cops choose Δ⁢𝐮n(0)∈ℛn⁢(G)\𝐮n−1(0)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛1\Delta\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n}\in\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)\backslash\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n-1}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and put pebbles (pin−1+1,pin−1+2,…,pin)subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛11subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛12…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛(p_{i_{n-1}+1},p_{i_{n-1}+2},\ldots,p_{i_{n}})( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) at Δ⁢𝐮n(0)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛\Delta\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. After Cops take the action, p1,…,pinsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{n}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should occupy 𝐮n(0)=(𝐮n−1(0),Δ⁢𝐮n(0))∈ℛn⁢(G)subscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛1Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑛subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n}=(\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n-1},\Delta\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{n})\in% \mathcal{R}_{n}(G)bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ).

    2. 2.

      Let X={u∈𝒱G:u⁢ is occupied by a pebble}𝑋conditional-set𝑢subscript𝒱𝐺𝑢 is occupied by a pebbleX=\{u\in\mathcal{V}_{G}:u\text{ is occupied by a pebble}\}italic_X = { italic_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_u is occupied by a pebble }. Robber chooses a connected component C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of G−X𝐺𝑋G-Xitalic_G - italic_X that satisfies C′⊆Csuperscript𝐶′𝐶C^{\prime}\subseteq Citalic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ italic_C, and updates his subset C𝐶Citalic_C to C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

    After all N𝑁Nitalic_N guarding moves, the main pebbles p1,…,pksubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘p_{1},\ldots,p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT should occupy some 𝐮N(0)∈ℛ⁢(G)subscriptsuperscript𝐮0𝑁ℛ𝐺\mathbf{u}^{(0)}_{N}\in\mathcal{R}(G)bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R ( italic_G ).

  • •

    After the initialization round, the two players repeatedly play the update round, each with M𝑀Mitalic_M guarding moves (numbered by m=1,…,M𝑚1…𝑀m=1,\ldots,Mitalic_m = 1 , … , italic_M) and one unguarding move.

    Throughout the M𝑀Mitalic_M guarding moves of the T𝑇Titalic_T-th update round, p1,…,pksubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘p_{1},\ldots,p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stay unmoved at 𝐮N(T−1)subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The game rule guarantees that before the m𝑚mitalic_m-th guarding move begins, the auxiliary pebbles pk+1,…,pk+jm−1subscript𝑝𝑘1…subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚1p_{k+1},\ldots,p_{k+j_{m-1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy a jm−1subscript𝑗𝑚1j_{m-1}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple 𝐮m−1′⁣(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of G𝐺Gitalic_G. The m𝑚mitalic_m-th guarding move goes as follows:

    1. 1.

      Cops choose Δ⁢𝐮m′⁣(T)∈ℱm⁢(G,𝐮N(T−1))\𝐮m−1′⁣(T)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚\subscriptℱ𝑚𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1\Delta\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m}\in\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N})% \backslash\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and put pebbles (pk+jm−1+1,(p_{k+j_{m-1}+1},( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , pk+jm−1+2,…,pk+jm)p_{k+j_{m-1}+2},\ldots,p_{k+j_{m}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) at Δ⁢𝐮m′⁣(T)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚\Delta\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. After Cops take the action, pk+1,…,pk+jmsubscript𝑝𝑘1…subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚p_{k+1},\ldots,p_{k+j_{m}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occupy 𝐮m′⁣(T)=(𝐮m−1′⁣(T),Δ⁢𝐮m′⁣(T))subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚1Δsubscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m}=(\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m-1},\Delta\mathbf{u}^{% \prime(T)}_{m})bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ℱm⁢(G,𝐮N(T−1))absentsubscriptℱ𝑚𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇1𝑁\in\mathcal{F}_{m}(G,\mathbf{u}^{(T-1)}_{N})∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

    2. 2.

      Let X={u∈𝒱G:u⁢ is occupied by a pebble}𝑋conditional-set𝑢subscript𝒱𝐺𝑢 is occupied by a pebbleX=\{u\in\mathcal{V}_{G}:u\text{ is occupied by a pebble}\}italic_X = { italic_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_u is occupied by a pebble }. Robber chooses a connected component C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of G−X𝐺𝑋G-Xitalic_G - italic_X that satisfies C′⊆Csuperscript𝐶′𝐶C^{\prime}\subseteq Citalic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ italic_C, and updates his subset C𝐶Citalic_C to C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

    After the M𝑀Mitalic_M guarding moves (now all (k+t)𝑘𝑡(k+t)( italic_k + italic_t ) pebbles should be on G𝐺Gitalic_G), the unguarding move goes as follows. Cops arbitrarily choose k𝑘kitalic_k indices r1,…,rk∈[k+t]subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑘delimited-[]𝑘𝑡r_{1},\ldots,r_{k}\in[k+t]italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_k + italic_t ] with r1<⋯<rksubscript𝑟1⋯subscript𝑟𝑘r_{1}<\cdots<r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ⋯ < italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. They then remove all pebbles on G𝐺Gitalic_G other than pr1,…,prksubscript𝑝subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑟𝑘p_{r_{1}},\ldots,p_{r_{k}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and relabel the pebbles such that prssubscript𝑝subscript𝑟𝑠p_{r_{s}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes pssubscript𝑝𝑠p_{s}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for s=1,…,k𝑠1…𝑘s=1,\ldots,kitalic_s = 1 , … , italic_k. After Cops are done, let X={u∈𝒱G:u⁢ is occupied by a pebble}𝑋conditional-set𝑢subscript𝒱𝐺𝑢 is occupied by a pebbleX=\{u\in\mathcal{V}_{G}:u\text{ is occupied by a pebble}\}italic_X = { italic_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_u is occupied by a pebble }. Robber chooses a connected component C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of G−X𝐺𝑋G-Xitalic_G - italic_X that satisfies C′⊇C𝐶superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}\supseteq Citalic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊇ italic_C, and updates his subset C𝐶Citalic_C to C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Finally, 𝐮N(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐮𝑇𝑁\mathbf{u}^{(T)}_{N}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is set to the new tuple occupied by (pebbles now labeled as) p1,…,pksubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑘p_{1},\ldots,p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

If Robber fails to find a connected component C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT according to the rule in some move, he is said to lose that move. Cops win the game if they can make Robber lose in some move. Robber wins the game if Cops can never win the game.

4.3 Homomorphism counting power of GFWL algorithms

In this subsection, we present our main result regarding the homomorphism counting power of generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms.

Definition 4.8.

Let 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) be a k𝑘kitalic_k-invariant function. 𝒜⁢(⋅)𝒜⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ ) is said to be closed under homomorphisms if for any G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G with a homomorphism hℎhitalic_h from G𝐺Gitalic_G to H𝐻Hitalic_H, holds h⁢(𝒜⁢(G))⊆𝒜⁢(H)ℎ𝒜𝐺𝒜𝐻h(\mathcal{A}(G))\subseteq\mathcal{A}(H)italic_h ( caligraphic_A ( italic_G ) ) ⊆ caligraphic_A ( italic_H ).

Definition 4.9.

Let 𝒜⁢(⋅,⋅)𝒜⋅⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) be an (ℓ,k)ℓ𝑘(\ell,k)( roman_ℓ , italic_k )-equivariant function. 𝒜⁢(⋅,⋅)𝒜⋅⋅\mathcal{A}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_A ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) is said to be closed under homomorphisms if for any G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G with a homomorphism hℎhitalic_h from G𝐺Gitalic_G to H𝐻Hitalic_H, and for any 𝐮∈𝒱Gℓ𝐮superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺ℓ\mathbf{u}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{\ell}bold_u ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, holds h⁢(𝒜⁢(G,𝐮))⊆𝒜⁢(H,h⁢(𝐮))ℎ𝒜𝐺𝐮𝒜𝐻ℎ𝐮h(\mathcal{A}(G,\mathbf{u}))\subseteq\mathcal{A}(H,h(\mathbf{u}))italic_h ( caligraphic_A ( italic_G , bold_u ) ) ⊆ caligraphic_A ( italic_H , italic_h ( bold_u ) ).

Our main theoretical result is the following theorem. It is assumed that Assumption 4.4 holds for the theorem.

Theorem 4.10.

Let F∈𝒢𝐹𝒢F\in\mathcal{G}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_G. Assume that ℛ⁢(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot)caligraphic_R ( ⋅ ) and ℱ⁢(⋅,⋅)ℱ⋅⋅\mathcal{F}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_F ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) in Assumption 4.4 are both closed under homomorphisms. Then the following two statements are equivalent:
(a). G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H get different colors W⁢(G)𝑊𝐺W(G)italic_W ( italic_G ) and W⁢(H)𝑊𝐻W(H)italic_W ( italic_H ) from the Weisfeiler-Leman algorithm;
(b). ∃F∈𝒢𝐹𝒢\exists F\in\mathcal{G}∃ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_G such that Cops win the Cops-Robber game on F𝐹Fitalic_F and that Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ).

Informally speaking, Theorem 4.10 determines that the set

{F∈𝒢:Cops win the Cops-Robber game on ⁢F}conditional-set𝐹𝒢Cops win the Cops-Robber game on 𝐹\displaystyle\{F\in\mathcal{G}:\text{Cops win the Cops-Robber game on }F\}{ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_G : Cops win the Cops-Robber game on italic_F } (15)

is exactly the set of query graphs whose homomorphisms a certain GFWL algorithm (defined by hyperparameters in Assumption 4.4) can count. The proof of Theorem 4.10 is split into two parts, each of which we summarize as a theorem below.

Theorem 4.11.

Let G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G. The following two statements are equivalent:
(a). G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H get different colors W⁢(G)𝑊𝐺W(G)italic_W ( italic_G ) and W⁢(H)𝑊𝐻W(H)italic_W ( italic_H ) from the Weisfeiler-Leman algorithm;
(b). Spoiler wins the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H.

Theorem 4.12.

Let G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G. Assume that ℛ⁢(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot)caligraphic_R ( ⋅ ) and ℱ⁢(⋅,⋅)ℱ⋅⋅\mathcal{F}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_F ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) are both closed under homomorphisms. Then the following two statements are equivalent:
(a). Spoiler wins the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H;
(b). ∃F∈𝒢𝐹𝒢\exists F\in\mathcal{G}∃ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_G such that Cops win the Cops-Robber game on F𝐹Fitalic_F and that Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ).

The proofs of Theorems 4.11 and 4.12 are given in Appendices B and C respectively.

5 Future directions

In this paper, we propose generalized folklore Weisfeiler-Leman algorithms to unify a number of existing designs of powerful GNNs. Currently, our framework is only suitable to describe GNNs (or WL variants) of folklore Weisfeiler-Leman (FWL) type. Since FWL-type variants usually achieves higher expressive power at the same computational complexities, it is practically acceptable to consider their homomorphism counting power only. Nevertheless, the homomorphism counting power of other variants of WL algorithms, such as k𝑘kitalic_k-WL [19], sparse k𝑘kitalic_k-WL [20] or subgraph WL [26], remains an interesting theoretic question. A future direction is to generalize our discussion on the homomorphism counting power of GFWL algorithms to those other variants. This would entail some modifications in the definitions of GFWL algorithms, as well as the two types of pebble games. In principle, the generalization would be straightforward.

Another more important question is the connection between homomorphism counting power and substructure counting power of WL variants. So far, only two works [21, 27] have yielded satisfactory results for some specific WL variants, namely k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL, subgraph k𝑘kitalic_k-WL, local k𝑘kitalic_k-WL and local 2-FWL. For all those mentioned WL variants, their ability to count subgraph isomorphisms from a query graph H𝐻Hitalic_H is shown to be equivalent to the ability to count subgraph homomorphisms from all graphs within 𝐒𝐩𝐚𝐬𝐦⁢(H)𝐒𝐩𝐚𝐬𝐦𝐻\bm{\mathrm{Spasm}(H)}bold_Spasm bold_( bold_italic_H bold_). However, it still remains unknown whether such result can be generalized to the case of GFWL. The hard point to establish such equivalence lies in the necessity to prove the monotonicity of Cops-Robber game (Definition 4.7) that corresponds to an arbitrary GFWL instance. As we have reviewed in Section 3, the monotonicity proof has been made for k𝑘kitalic_k-FWL [9, 23], and the other three variants listed above [27]. The proof methodologies in those works cannot be easily generalized to the case of GFWL. Therefore, we leave the general monotonicity proof for GFWL, as well as the problem of determining the exact substructure counting power of GFWL, to future works.
