      φ(T):u1(T)↦w1(T)=wr1(cT)(T−1),…,uk(T)↦wk(T)=wrk(cT)(T−1).\displaystyle\varphi^{(T)}:\quad u_{1}^{(T)}\mapsto w_{1}^{(T)}=w^{(T-1)}_{r_{% 1}^{(c_{T})}},\ldots,u^{(T)}_{k}\mapsto w_{k}^{(T)}=w^{(T-1)}_{r_{k}^{(c_{T})}}.italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ↦ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ↦ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (49)

      One can easily show that φ(T)superscript𝜑𝑇\varphi^{(T)}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an isomorphism from G⁢[𝐮N(T)]𝐺delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑁𝑇G[\mathbf{u}_{N}^{(T)}]italic_G [ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] to the subgraph of F(T)⁢(G,a)superscript𝐹𝑇𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) induced by (w1(T),…,wk(T))superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑇…superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑇(w_{1}^{(T)},\ldots,w_{k}^{(T)})( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

The graph Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) is called Spoiler’s record graph up to the p𝑝pitalic_p-th move of the T𝑇Titalic_T-th round, where T⩾0𝑇0T\geqslant 0italic_T ⩾ 0, and p𝑝pitalic_p is an integer in {0,1,…,N}01…𝑁\{0,1,\ldots,N\}{ 0 , 1 , … , italic_N } for T=0𝑇0T=0italic_T = 0, or in {0,1,…,M}01…𝑀\{0,1,\ldots,M\}{ 0 , 1 , … , italic_M } for T⩾1𝑇1T\geqslant 1italic_T ⩾ 1.

The following lemma is straightforward.

Lemma C.2.

Let ≼precedes-or-equals\preccurlyeq≼ be a partial order on 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G such that ∀G,H∈𝒢for-all𝐺𝐻𝒢\forall G,H\in\mathcal{G}∀ italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G, G≼Hprecedes-or-equals𝐺𝐻G\preccurlyeq Hitalic_G ≼ italic_H if and only if G𝐺Gitalic_G is an induced subgraph of H𝐻Hitalic_H. Then we have

F0(0)⁢(G,a)≼F1(0)⁢(G,a)≼⋯precedes-or-equalssubscriptsuperscript𝐹00𝐺𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝐹01𝐺𝑎precedes-or-equals⋯\displaystyle F^{(0)}_{0}(G,a)\preccurlyeq F^{(0)}_{1}(G,a)\preccurlyeq\cdotsitalic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) ≼ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) ≼ ⋯ ≼FN(0)⁢(G,a)=F0(1)⁢(G,a)≼F1(1)⁢(G,a)≼⋯precedes-or-equalsabsentsubscriptsuperscript𝐹0𝑁𝐺𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝐹10𝐺𝑎precedes-or-equalssubscriptsuperscript𝐹11𝐺𝑎precedes-or-equals⋯\displaystyle\preccurlyeq F^{(0)}_{N}(G,a)=F^{(1)}_{0}(G,a)\preccurlyeq F^{(1)% }_{1}(G,a)\preccurlyeq\cdots≼ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) = italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) ≼ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) ≼ ⋯
≼FM(1)⁢(G,a)=F0(2)⁢(G,a)≼F1(2)⁢(G,a)≼⋯≼⋯,precedes-or-equalsabsentsubscriptsuperscript𝐹1𝑀𝐺𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝐹20𝐺𝑎precedes-or-equalssubscriptsuperscript𝐹21𝐺𝑎precedes-or-equals⋯precedes-or-equals⋯\displaystyle\preccurlyeq F^{(1)}_{M}(G,a)=F^{(2)}_{0}(G,a)\preccurlyeq F^{(2)% }_{1}(G,a)\preccurlyeq\cdots\preccurlyeq\cdots,≼ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) = italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) ≼ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) ≼ ⋯ ≼ ⋯ , (50)

for any G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and any action sequence a𝑎aitalic_a of Spoiler on G𝐺Gitalic_G.

The following lemma is essential for our proof.

Lemma C.3.

Given any T⩾0𝑇0T\geqslant 0italic_T ⩾ 0 and p∈[N]𝑝delimited-[]𝑁p\in[N]italic_p ∈ [ italic_N ] (if T=0𝑇0T=0italic_T = 0) or p∈[M]𝑝delimited-[]𝑀p\in[M]italic_p ∈ [ italic_M ] (if T⩾1𝑇1T\geqslant 1italic_T ⩾ 1), Cops win the Cops-Robber game on Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ), with any G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and any action sequence a𝑎aitalic_a of Spoiler on G𝐺Gitalic_G.

Proof of Lemma C.3. Cops’ winning strategy is given below: for the n𝑛nitalic_n-th (1⩽n⩽N1𝑛𝑁1\leqslant n\leqslant N1 ⩽ italic_n ⩽ italic_N) guarding move of the initialization round, they put new pebbles at win−1+1(0),…,win(0)superscriptsubscript𝑤subscript𝑖𝑛110…superscriptsubscript𝑤subscript𝑖𝑛0w_{i_{n-1}+1}^{(0)},\ldots,w_{i_{n}}^{(0)}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; for the m𝑚mitalic_m-th (1⩽m⩽M1𝑚𝑀1\leqslant m\leqslant M1 ⩽ italic_m ⩽ italic_M) guarding move of the T~~𝑇\tilde{T}over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG-th (T~⩾1~𝑇1\tilde{T}\geqslant 1over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ⩾ 1) update round, they put new pebbles at wk+jm−1+1(T~−1),…,wk+jm(T~−1)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚11~𝑇1…superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚~𝑇1w_{k+j_{m-1}+1}^{(\tilde{T}-1)},\ldots,w_{k+j_{m}}^{(\tilde{T}-1)}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; for the unguarding move of the T~~𝑇\tilde{T}over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG-th (T~⩾1~𝑇1\tilde{T}\geqslant 1over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ⩾ 1) update round, they choose the sequence (r1(cT~),…,rk(cT~))superscriptsubscript𝑟1subscript𝑐~𝑇…superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘subscript𝑐~𝑇(r_{1}^{(c_{\tilde{T}})},\ldots,r_{k}^{(c_{\tilde{T}})})( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

One can verify that by implementing the above strategy, Cops can guarantee that the set of edges C𝐶Citalic_C chosen by Robber after the p~~𝑝\tilde{p}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG-th guarding move of the T~~𝑇\tilde{T}over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG-th update round (1⩽p~⩽N1~𝑝𝑁1\leqslant\tilde{p}\leqslant N1 ⩽ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ⩽ italic_N for T~=0~𝑇0\tilde{T}=0over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG = 0 and 1⩽p~⩽M1~𝑝𝑀1\leqslant\tilde{p}\leqslant M1 ⩽ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ⩽ italic_M for T~⩾1~𝑇1\tilde{T}\geqslant 1over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ⩾ 1) satisfies C∩ℰFp~(T~)⁢(G,a)=∅𝐶subscriptℰsubscriptsuperscript𝐹~𝑇~𝑝𝐺𝑎C\cap\mathcal{E}_{F^{(\tilde{T})}_{\tilde{p}}(G,a)}=\varnothingitalic_C ∩ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∅; additionally, C𝐶Citalic_C remains unchanged after every unguarding move. Therefore, after the p𝑝pitalic_p-th guarding move of the T𝑇Titalic_T-th update round, Robber must lose.
End of proof of Lemma C.3.

Now we can give the construction of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S. Given T⩾0𝑇0T\geqslant 0italic_T ⩾ 0 and p∈[N]𝑝delimited-[]𝑁p\in[N]italic_p ∈ [ italic_N ] (for T=0𝑇0T=0italic_T = 0) or p∈[M]𝑝delimited-[]𝑀p\in[M]italic_p ∈ [ italic_M ] (for T⩾1𝑇1T\geqslant 1italic_T ⩾ 1), define

𝒮p(T)={Fp(T)⁢(G,a):G∈𝒢,a⁢ is an action sequence of Spoiler on ⁢G}.subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝑇𝑝conditional-setsubscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎𝐺𝒢𝑎 is an action sequence of Spoiler on 𝐺\displaystyle\mathcal{S}^{(T)}_{p}=\{F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a):G\in\mathcal{G},a\text{ % is an action sequence of Spoiler on }G\}.caligraphic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) : italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G , italic_a is an action sequence of Spoiler on italic_G } . (51)

Due to (a), there exists T∗⩾0superscript𝑇0T^{*}\geqslant 0italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⩾ 0 such that Spoiler can guarantee to win the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game no later than the T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th update round ends. We then let

𝒮=⋃T=0T∗⋃p=1N⁢, if ⁢T=0M⁢, if ⁢T⩾1𝒮p(T).𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑇0superscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑁, if 𝑇0𝑀, if 𝑇1subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝑇𝑝\displaystyle\mathcal{S}=\bigcup_{T=0}^{T^{*}}\bigcup_{p=1}^{\begin{subarray}{% c}N\text{, if }T=0\\ M\text{, if }T\geqslant 1\end{subarray}}\mathcal{S}^{(T)}_{p}.caligraphic_S = ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_N , if italic_T = 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_M , if italic_T ⩾ 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (52)
Definition C.4.

Given G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and an action sequence a𝑎aitalic_a of Spoiler on G𝐺Gitalic_G, each of the following tuples is called a bag:

𝐰n(0)=(w1(0),…,win(0))∈𝒱Fn(0)⁢(G,a)in,superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝑤10…superscriptsubscript𝑤subscript𝑖𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝐹0𝑛𝐺𝑎subscript𝑖𝑛\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(0)}=(w_{1}^{(0)},\ldots,w_{i_{n}}^{(0)})\in% \mathcal{V}_{F^{(0)}_{n}(G,a)}^{i_{n}},bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 1⩽n⩽N,1𝑛𝑁\displaystyle 1\leqslant n\leqslant N,1 ⩽ italic_n ⩽ italic_N , (53)
𝐰m(T)=(w1(T−1),…,wk+jm(T−1))∈𝒱Fm(T)⁢(G,a)k+jm,superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑇1…superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑚𝐺𝑎𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{m}^{(T)}=(w_{1}^{(T-1)},\ldots,w_{k+j_{m}}^{(T-1)})% \in\mathcal{V}_{F^{(T)}_{m}(G,a)}^{k+j_{m}},bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , T⩾1,1⩽m⩽M.formulae-sequence𝑇11𝑚𝑀\displaystyle T\geqslant 1,1\leqslant m\leqslant M.italic_T ⩾ 1 , 1 ⩽ italic_m ⩽ italic_M . (54)

They are exactly the ranges of φn(0)superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑛0\varphi_{n}^{(0)}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (for 𝐰n(0)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛0\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(0)}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) or φm(T)superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑚𝑇\varphi_{m}^{(T)}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (for 𝐰m(T)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑇\mathbf{w}_{m}^{(T)}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

Due to Lemma C.2, Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) contains all bags 𝐰p~(T~)subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑇~𝑝\mathbf{w}^{(\tilde{T})}_{\tilde{p}}bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that satisfy T~<T~𝑇𝑇\tilde{T}<Tover~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG < italic_T or T~=T,p~⩽pformulae-sequence~𝑇𝑇~𝑝𝑝\tilde{T}=T,\tilde{p}\leqslant pover~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG = italic_T , over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ⩽ italic_p.

Lemma C.5.

𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S is a finite set.

Proof of Lemma C.5. For given T𝑇Titalic_T and p𝑝pitalic_p values, the number of bags present in Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) is determined. Furthermore, Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) is uniquely determined up to isomorphism by the isomorphism types of the bags it contains. Since the number of possible isomorphism types of each bag is finite, the set 𝒮p(T)subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝑇𝑝\mathcal{S}^{(T)}_{p}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is finite, given any T⩾0𝑇0T\geqslant 0italic_T ⩾ 0, and p∈[N]𝑝delimited-[]𝑁p\in[N]italic_p ∈ [ italic_N ] for T=0𝑇0T=0italic_T = 0 or p∈[M]𝑝delimited-[]𝑀p\in[M]italic_p ∈ [ italic_M ] for T⩾1𝑇1T\geqslant 1italic_T ⩾ 1. Hence 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S is finite.
End of proof of Lemma C.5.

Definition C.6.

Let Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) be a Spoiler’s record graph. For any H∈𝒢𝐻𝒢H\in\mathcal{G}italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G, a bag-wise isomorphic homomorphism from Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) to H𝐻Hitalic_H is a homomorphism h:𝒱Fp(T)⁢(G,a)→𝒱H:ℎ→subscript𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎subscript𝒱𝐻h:\mathcal{V}_{F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)}\rightarrow\mathcal{V}_{H}italic_h : caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that for every bag 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w present in Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ), hℎhitalic_h is an isomorphism from Fp(T)⁢(G,a)⁢[𝐰]subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎delimited-[]𝐰F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)[\mathbf{w}]italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) [ bold_w ] to H⁢[h⁢(𝐰)]𝐻delimited-[]ℎ𝐰H[h(\mathbf{w})]italic_H [ italic_h ( bold_w ) ]. The number of bag-wise isomorphic homomorphisms from Fp(T)⁢(G,a)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a)italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) to H𝐻Hitalic_H is denoted as bIsoHom⁢(Fp(T)⁢(G,a),H)bIsoHomsubscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑝𝐺𝑎𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F^{(T)}_{p}(G,a),H)roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G , italic_a ) , italic_H ).

Lemma C.7.

Assume that Spoiler wins the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H no later than the T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th update round ends. Then ∃F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮\exists F\in\mathcal{S}∃ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S that satisfies

bIsoHom⁢(F,G)≠bIsoHom⁢(F,H).bIsoHom𝐹𝐺bIsoHom𝐹𝐻\displaystyle\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,H).roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_H ) . (55)

Proof of Lemma C.7. Assume that the contrary is the case. Namely, ∀F∈𝒮for-all𝐹𝒮\forall F\in\mathcal{S}∀ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S, bIsoHom⁢(F,G)=bIsoHom⁢(F,H)bIsoHom𝐹𝐺bIsoHom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,G)=\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,H)roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_G ) = roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_H ). We can prove that Duplicator will not lose the game in the first (T∗+1)superscript𝑇1(T^{*}+1)( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 ) rounds, by explicitly constructing a strategy for Duplicator.

By our assumption above, given any F1(0)⁢(G~,a~)∈𝒮1(0)subscriptsuperscript𝐹01~𝐺~𝑎superscriptsubscript𝒮10F^{(0)}_{1}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a})\in\mathcal{S}_{1}^{(0)}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have bIsoHom⁢(F1(0)⁢(G~,a~),G)=bIsoHom⁢(F1(0)⁢(G~,a~),H)bIsoHomsubscriptsuperscript𝐹01~𝐺~𝑎𝐺bIsoHomsubscriptsuperscript𝐹01~𝐺~𝑎𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F^{(0)}_{1}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a}),G)=\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F^{(0)}_% {1}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a}),H)roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) , italic_G ) = roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) , italic_H ), where G~∈𝒢~𝐺𝒢\tilde{G}\in\mathcal{G}over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_G is an arbitrary graph, while a~~𝑎\tilde{a}over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG is an action sequence on G~~𝐺\tilde{G}over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. Since F1(0)⁢(G~,a~)subscriptsuperscript𝐹01~𝐺~𝑎F^{(0)}_{1}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a})italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) contains only one bag 𝐰1(0)subscriptsuperscript𝐰01\mathbf{w}^{(0)}_{1}bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the above fact implies

|{𝐮1(0)∈𝒱Gi1:atp⁢(𝐮1(0))=atp⁢(𝐰1(0))}|=|{𝐯1(0)∈𝒱Hi1:atp⁢(𝐯1(0))=atp⁢(𝐰1(0))}|.conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐮10superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝑖1atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐮10atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰10conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐯10superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻subscript𝑖1atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐯10atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰10\displaystyle\big{|}\{\mathbf{u}_{1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{i_{1}}:\mathrm{% atp}(\mathbf{u}_{1}^{(0)})=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{(0)})\}\big{|}=\big{|}% \{\mathbf{v}_{1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{V}_{H}^{i_{1}}:\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v}_{1}^{% (0)})=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{(0)})\}\big{|}.| { bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : roman_atp ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } | = | { bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : roman_atp ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } | . (56)

Equation (56) holds for any F1(0)⁢(G~,a~)∈𝒮1(0)subscriptsuperscript𝐹01~𝐺~𝑎superscriptsubscript𝒮10F^{(0)}_{1}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a})\in\mathcal{S}_{1}^{(0)}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in which different choices of G~~𝐺\tilde{G}over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG and a~~𝑎\tilde{a}over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG may lead to different atp⁢(𝐰1(0))atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰10\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{(0)})roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). If atp⁢(𝐰1(0))atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰10\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{(0)})roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) can traverse over In other words, Duplicator will not lose after the first putting move of the initialization round.

We now show that this is indeed the case; namely, by choosing different G~~𝐺\tilde{G}over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG and a~~𝑎\tilde{a}over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG, the corresponding atp⁢(𝐰1(0))atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰10\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{(0)})roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) does encompass every possible isomorphism type of 𝐮1(0)∈ℛ1⁢(G)superscriptsubscript𝐮10subscriptℛ1𝐺\mathbf{u}_{1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) or 𝐯1(0)∈ℛ1⁢(H)superscriptsubscript𝐯10subscriptℛ1𝐻\mathbf{v}_{1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ). Notice that 𝐰1(0)∈𝒱F1(0)⁢(G~,a~)i1subscriptsuperscript𝐰01superscriptsubscript𝒱subscriptsuperscript𝐹01~𝐺~𝑎subscript𝑖1\mathbf{w}^{(0)}_{1}\in\mathcal{V}_{F^{(0)}_{1}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a})}^{i_{1}}bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the isomorphism image (via φ1(0)subscriptsuperscript𝜑01\varphi^{(0)}_{1}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) of some 𝐮~1(0)∈ℛ1⁢(G~)subscriptsuperscript~𝐮01subscriptℛ1~𝐺\tilde{\mathbf{u}}^{(0)}_{1}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(\tilde{G})over~ start_ARG bold_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG ). When traversing over all G~~𝐺\tilde{G}over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG and a~~𝑎\tilde{a}over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG, the value space of atp⁢(𝐰1(0))atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰10\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{1}^{(0)})roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is actually

which is definitely a superset of {atp⁢(𝐮1(0)):𝐮1(0)∈ℛ1⁢(G)}conditional-setatpsuperscriptsubscript𝐮10superscriptsubscript𝐮10subscriptℛ1𝐺\{\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{u}_{1}^{(0)}):\mathbf{u}_{1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)\}{ roman_atp ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) : bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) } and {atp⁢(𝐯1(0)):𝐯1(0)∈ℛ1⁢(H)}conditional-setatpsuperscriptsubscript𝐯10superscriptsubscript𝐯10subscriptℛ1𝐻\{\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v}_{1}^{(0)}):\mathbf{v}_{1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)\}{ roman_atp ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) : bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ) }.

Similarly, for 2⩽n⩽N2𝑛𝑁2\leqslant n\leqslant N2 ⩽ italic_n ⩽ italic_N, the fact that ∀Fn(0)⁢(G~,a~)∈𝒮n(0)for-allsubscriptsuperscript𝐹0𝑛~𝐺~𝑎superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑛0\forall F^{(0)}_{n}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a})\in\mathcal{S}_{n}^{(0)}∀ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, bIsoHom⁢(Fn(0)⁢(G~,a~),G)=bIsoHom⁢(Fn(0)⁢(G~,a~),H)bIsoHomsubscriptsuperscript𝐹0𝑛~𝐺~𝑎𝐺bIsoHomsubscriptsuperscript𝐹0𝑛~𝐺~𝑎𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F^{(0)}_{n}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a}),G)=\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F^{(0)}_% {n}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a}),H)roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) , italic_G ) = roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) , italic_H ) implies that

|{𝐮n(0)∈𝒱Gin:atp⁢(𝐮n(0))=atp⁢(𝐰n(0))}|=|{𝐯n(0)∈𝒱Hin:atp⁢(𝐯n(0))=atp⁢(𝐰n(0))}|.conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝑖𝑛atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛0conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻subscript𝑖𝑛atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛0atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛0\displaystyle\big{|}\{\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{i_{n}}:\mathrm{% atp}(\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)})=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(0)})\}\big{|}=\big{|}% \{\mathbf{v}_{n}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{V}_{H}^{i_{n}}:\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v}_{n}^{% (0)})=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(0)})\}\big{|}.| { bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : roman_atp ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } | = | { bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : roman_atp ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } | . (58)

With a completely analogous argument, we will find that there exists a bijection f′:ℛn⁢(G)→ℛn⁢(H):superscript𝑓′→subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺subscriptℛ𝑛𝐻f^{\prime}:\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)\rightarrow\mathcal{R}_{n}(H)italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) → caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ), such that for any 𝐮n(0)∈ℛn⁢(G)superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) and 𝐯n(0)=f′⁢(𝐮n(0))∈ℛn⁢(H)superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛0superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0subscriptℛ𝑛𝐻\mathbf{v}_{n}^{(0)}=f^{\prime}(\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)})\in\mathcal{R}_{n}(H)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ), holds atp⁢(𝐮n(0))=atp⁢(𝐯n(0))atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛0\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)})=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{v}_{n}^{(0)})roman_atp ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_atp ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Assuming that Duplicator has not lost after the (n−1)𝑛1(n-1)( italic_n - 1 )-th putting move of the initialization round, the tuples 𝐮n−1(0)∈𝒱Gin−1superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺subscript𝑖𝑛1\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{i_{n-1}}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐯n−1(0)∈𝒱Hin−1superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛10superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻subscript𝑖𝑛1\mathbf{v}_{n-1}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{V}_{H}^{i_{n-1}}bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (occupied by pebbles p1,…,pin−1subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛1p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{n-1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and q1,…,qin−1subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞subscript𝑖𝑛1q_{1},\ldots,q_{i_{n-1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively) should have the same isomorphism type. If we restrict the bijection f′superscript𝑓′f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on

{(𝐮n−1(0),Δ⁢𝐮n(0)):Δ⁢𝐮n(0)∈ℛn⁢(G)\𝐮n−1(0)},conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10\displaystyle\{(\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)},\Delta\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}):\Delta% \mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)\backslash\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)}\},{ ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) : roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ,

we can easily see that Duplicator can choose the bijection f:ℛn⁢(G)\𝐮n−1(0)→ℛn⁢(H)\𝐯n−1(0):𝑓→\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐻superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛10f:\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)\backslash\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}_{n}% (H)\backslash\mathbf{v}_{n-1}^{(0)}italic_f : caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ) \ bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that f′⁢((𝐮n−1(0),Δ⁢𝐮n(0)))=(𝐯n−1(0),f⁢(Δ⁢𝐮n(0)))superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑛10𝑓Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0f^{\prime}((\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)},\Delta\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}))=(\mathbf{v}_{n% -1}^{(0)},f(\Delta\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}))italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) = ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f ( roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) for any Δ⁢𝐮n(0)∈ℛn⁢(G)\𝐮n−1(0)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛0\subscriptℛ𝑛𝐺superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑛10\Delta\mathbf{u}_{n}^{(0)}\in\mathcal{R}_{n}(G)\backslash\mathbf{u}_{n-1}^{(0)}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By doing so, Duplicator will continue to survive the n𝑛nitalic_n-th putting move of the initialization round. By induction, we have proved that Duplicator can prevent herself from losing in the initialization round.

The above technique can also be used to find Duplicator’s strategy for the m𝑚mitalic_m-th putting move of the T𝑇Titalic_T-th update round, with 1⩽T⩽T∗1𝑇superscript𝑇1\leqslant T\leqslant T^{*}1 ⩽ italic_T ⩽ italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 1⩽m⩽M1𝑚𝑀1\leqslant m\leqslant M1 ⩽ italic_m ⩽ italic_M. We only need to replace (58) with

|{(𝐮N(T−1),𝐮m′⁣(T))∈𝒱Gk+jm:atp⁢((𝐮N(T−1),𝐮m′⁣(T)))=atp⁢(𝐰m(T))}|conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑁𝑇1subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐮𝑁𝑇1subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑇𝑚atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑇\displaystyle\big{|}\{(\mathbf{u}_{N}^{(T-1)},\mathbf{u}^{\prime(T)}_{m})\in% \mathcal{V}_{G}^{k+j_{m}}:\mathrm{atp}((\mathbf{u}_{N}^{(T-1)},\mathbf{u}^{% \prime(T)}_{m}))=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{m}^{(T)})\}\big{|}| { ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : roman_atp ( ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } |
=|{(𝐯N(T−1),𝐯m′⁣(T))∈𝒱Hk+jm:atp⁢((𝐯N(T−1),𝐯m′⁣(T)))=atp⁢(𝐰m(T))}|,absentconditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑁𝑇1subscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑇𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐻𝑘subscript𝑗𝑚atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑁𝑇1subscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑇𝑚atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑇\displaystyle=\big{|}\{(\mathbf{v}_{N}^{(T-1)},\mathbf{v}^{\prime(T)}_{m})\in% \mathcal{V}_{H}^{k+j_{m}}:\mathrm{atp}((\mathbf{v}_{N}^{(T-1)},\mathbf{v}^{% \prime(T)}_{m}))=\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{m}^{(T)})\}\big{|},= | { ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : roman_atp ( ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } | , (59)

where atp⁢(𝐰m(T))atpsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑚𝑇\mathrm{atp}(\mathbf{w}_{m}^{(T)})roman_atp ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) traverses over

⋃G~∈𝒢{atp⁢((𝐮~,𝐮~′)):𝐮~∈ℛ⁢(G~),𝐮~′∈ℱm⁢(G~,𝐮~)},subscript~𝐺𝒢conditional-setatp~𝐮superscript~𝐮′formulae-sequence~𝐮ℛ~𝐺superscript~𝐮′subscriptℱ𝑚~𝐺~𝐮\displaystyle\bigcup_{\tilde{G}\in\mathcal{G}}\{\mathrm{atp}((\tilde{\mathbf{u% }},\tilde{\mathbf{u}}^{\prime})):\tilde{\mathbf{u}}\in\mathcal{R}(\tilde{G}),% \tilde{\mathbf{u}}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{F}_{m}(\tilde{G},\tilde{\mathbf{u}})\},⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { roman_atp ( ( over~ start_ARG bold_u end_ARG , over~ start_ARG bold_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) : over~ start_ARG bold_u end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_R ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG ) , over~ start_ARG bold_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG bold_u end_ARG ) } , (60)

as we consider all graphs Fm(T)⁢(G~,a~)∈𝒮m(T)subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝑇𝑚~𝐺~𝑎superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑚𝑇F^{(T)}_{m}(\tilde{G},\tilde{a})\in\mathcal{S}_{m}^{(T)}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG ) ∈ caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. With an argument similar to above, one can show that Duplicator indeed survives the m𝑚mitalic_m-th putting move of the T𝑇Titalic_T-th update round, given that she has survived the (m−1)𝑚1(m-1)( italic_m - 1 )-th putting move. Finally, the removing move poses no threats to Duplicator, if she has not lost after all M𝑀Mitalic_M putting moves in an update round.

Combining all the above results, we conclude that Duplicator can ensure that she will not lose the game in the first (T∗+1)superscript𝑇1(T^{*}+1)( italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 ) rounds, a result contradicting the assumption that Spoiler can win no later than the T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th update round ends. Therefore, Lemma C.7 is true.
End of proof of Lemma C.7.

We now turn to proving (a) ⇒⇒\Rightarrow⇒ (b). As in the above discussion, we assume that Spoiler wins the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H no later than the T∗superscript𝑇T^{*}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th update round ends. Our desired result is that ∃F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮\exists F\in\mathcal{S}∃ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S, Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ). In Lemma C.7, we have already proved something similar, i.e., ∃F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮\exists F\in\mathcal{S}∃ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S, bIsoHom⁢(F,G)≠bIsoHom⁢(F,H)bIsoHom𝐹𝐺bIsoHom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,H)roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_H ). To bridge the gap, it suffices to find connections between Hom⁢(F,G)Hom𝐹𝐺\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) and bIsoHom⁢(F,G)bIsoHom𝐹𝐺\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,G)roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_G ), for F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮F\in\mathcal{S}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S and G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G.

Definition C.8.

Assume that F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮F\in\mathcal{S}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S and 𝐰=(w1,…,ws)∈𝒱Fs𝐰subscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐹𝑠\mathbf{w}=(w_{1},\ldots,w_{s})\in\mathcal{V}_{F}^{s}bold_w = ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a bag in F𝐹Fitalic_F. Further assume that wi≠wjsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑤𝑗w_{i}\neq w_{j}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {wi,wj}∉ℰFsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑤𝑗subscriptℰ𝐹\{w_{i},w_{j}\}\notin\mathcal{E}_{F}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ∉ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some i,j∈[s]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑠i,j\in[s]italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_s ]. Define two operations on F𝐹Fitalic_F:
(i) Bag extension. Let F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the graph obtained by adding an edge {wi,wj}subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑤𝑗\{w_{i},w_{j}\}{ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } to F𝐹Fitalic_F. We say that F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained by extending the bag 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w in F𝐹Fitalic_F.
(ii) Bag surjection image. Let F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the graph obtained by removing node wjsubscript𝑤𝑗w_{j}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in F𝐹Fitalic_F, and then adding an edge between wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and every node that is adjacent to wjsubscript𝑤𝑗w_{j}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but not adjacent to wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in F𝐹Fitalic_F. We say that F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained by taking surjection image of bag 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w in F𝐹Fitalic_F.

From Definition C.8, one can easily see that if F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained by extending (or taking surjection image of) a bag 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w in F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮F\in\mathcal{S}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S, then there exists an in-bag homomorphism hℎhitalic_h from F𝐹Fitalic_F to F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which satisfies (i) hℎhitalic_h is surjective, and (ii) u≠v⇔h⁢(u)≠h⁢(v)⇔𝑢𝑣ℎ𝑢ℎ𝑣u\neq v\Leftrightarrow h(u)\neq h(v)italic_u ≠ italic_v ⇔ italic_h ( italic_u ) ≠ italic_h ( italic_v ) and {u,v}∈ℰF⇔{h⁢(u),h⁢(v)}∈ℰF′⇔𝑢𝑣subscriptℰ𝐹ℎ𝑢ℎ𝑣subscriptℰsuperscript𝐹′\{u,v\}\in\mathcal{E}_{F}\Leftrightarrow\{h(u),h(v)\}\in\mathcal{E}_{F^{\prime}}{ italic_u , italic_v } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⇔ { italic_h ( italic_u ) , italic_h ( italic_v ) } ∈ caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if no single bag in F𝐹Fitalic_F contains both u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v. Furthermore, we have

{atp⁢(h⁢(𝐰~p~(T~))):F∈𝒮⁢ and ⁢F⁢ contains the bag ⁢𝐰~p~(T~)}conditional-setatpℎsubscriptsuperscript~𝐰~𝑇~𝑝𝐹𝒮 and 𝐹 contains the bag subscriptsuperscript~𝐰~𝑇~𝑝\displaystyle\{\mathrm{atp}(h(\tilde{\mathbf{w}}^{(\tilde{T})}_{\tilde{p}})):F% \in\mathcal{S}\text{ and }F\text{ contains the bag }\tilde{\mathbf{w}}^{(% \tilde{T})}_{\tilde{p}}\}{ roman_atp ( italic_h ( over~ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) : italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S and italic_F contains the bag over~ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }
⊆{atp⁢(𝐰~p~(T~)):F∈𝒮⁢ and ⁢F⁢ contains the bag ⁢𝐰~p~(T~)},absentconditional-setatpsubscriptsuperscript~𝐰~𝑇~𝑝𝐹𝒮 and 𝐹 contains the bag subscriptsuperscript~𝐰~𝑇~𝑝\displaystyle\subseteq\{\mathrm{atp}(\tilde{\mathbf{w}}^{(\tilde{T})}_{\tilde{% p}}):F\in\mathcal{S}\text{ and }F\text{ contains the bag }\tilde{\mathbf{w}}^{% (\tilde{T})}_{\tilde{p}}\},⊆ { roman_atp ( over~ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S and italic_F contains the bag over~ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , (61)

by our assumption that ℛ⁢(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot)caligraphic_R ( ⋅ ) and ℱ⁢(⋅,⋅)ℱ⋅⋅\mathcal{F}(\cdot,\cdot)caligraphic_F ( ⋅ , ⋅ ) are both closed under homomorphisms. Equation (61) implies that the image of every bag in F𝐹Fitalic_F under hℎhitalic_h has the isomorphism type of a valid bag. Therefore, we assert that F′∈𝒮superscript𝐹′𝒮F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S. In other words, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S is closed under bag extension and taking bag surjection images.

In the following, we use bInHom⁢(F,F′)bInHom𝐹superscript𝐹′\mathrm{bInHom}(F,F^{\prime})roman_bInHom ( italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) to denote the number of in-bag homomorphisms from F𝐹Fitalic_F to F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, if F=F′𝐹superscript𝐹′F=F^{\prime}italic_F = italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, or if F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be obtained by taking a series of bag extension or bag surjection image operations on F𝐹Fitalic_F, given F,F′∈𝒮𝐹superscript𝐹′𝒮F,F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S. If neither of above is the case, we define bInHom⁢(F,F′)=0bInHom𝐹superscript𝐹′0\mathrm{bInHom}(F,F^{\prime})=0roman_bInHom ( italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. Notice that bInHom⁢(F,F′)≠0bInHom𝐹superscript𝐹′0\mathrm{bInHom}(F,F^{\prime})\neq 0roman_bInHom ( italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ 0 only if F𝐹Fitalic_F and F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT lie in the same set 𝒮p(T)subscriptsuperscript𝒮𝑇𝑝\mathcal{S}^{(T)}_{p}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_T ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some T𝑇Titalic_T and p𝑝pitalic_p.

One can see that the following identity holds for any F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮F\in\mathcal{S}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S and G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G,

Hom⁢(F,G)=∑F′∈𝒮bInHom⁢(F,F′)bAut⁢(F′)⋅bIsoHom⁢(F′,G),Hom𝐹𝐺subscriptsuperscript𝐹′𝒮⋅bInHom𝐹superscript𝐹′bAutsuperscript𝐹′bIsoHomsuperscript𝐹′𝐺\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)=\sum_{F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}}\frac{\mathrm{% bInHom}(F,F^{\prime})}{\mathrm{bAut}(F^{\prime})}\cdot\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F^{% \prime},G),roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_bInHom ( italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_bAut ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ⋅ roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G ) , (62)

in which bAut⁢(F′)bAutsuperscript𝐹′\mathrm{bAut}(F^{\prime})roman_bAut ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (F′∈𝒮superscript𝐹′𝒮F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S) is the number of automorphisms of F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is an automorphism of F′⁢[𝐰]superscript𝐹′delimited-[]𝐰F^{\prime}[\mathbf{w}]italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ bold_w ] for any bag 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w in F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The above identity can be rewritten in matrix form, namely

HomG=bInHom⋅bAut−1⋅bIsoHomG,subscriptHom𝐺⋅bInHomsuperscriptbAut1subscriptbIsoHom𝐺\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}_{G}=\mathrm{bInHom}\cdot\mathrm{bAut}^{-1}\cdot% \mathrm{bIsoHom}_{G},roman_Hom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_bInHom ⋅ roman_bAut start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ roman_bIsoHom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (63)

where HomG=[Hom⁢(F,G)]F∈𝒮subscriptHom𝐺subscriptdelimited-[]Hom𝐹𝐺𝐹𝒮\mathrm{Hom}_{G}=[\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)]_{F\in\mathcal{S}}roman_Hom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bIsoHomG=[bIsoHom⁢(F,G)]F∈𝒮subscriptbIsoHom𝐺subscriptdelimited-[]bIsoHom𝐹𝐺𝐹𝒮\mathrm{bIsoHom}_{G}=[\mathrm{bIsoHom}(F,G)]_{F\in\mathcal{S}}roman_bIsoHom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ roman_bIsoHom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are column vectors, given G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G, while bInHom=[bInHom⁢(F,F′)]F,F′∈𝒮bInHomsubscriptdelimited-[]bInHom𝐹superscript𝐹′𝐹superscript𝐹′𝒮\mathrm{bInHom}=[\mathrm{bInHom}(F,F^{\prime})]_{F,F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S}}roman_bInHom = [ roman_bInHom ( italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bAut=diag⁢[bAut⁢(F)]F∈𝒮bAutdiagsubscriptdelimited-[]bAut𝐹𝐹𝒮\mathrm{bAut}=\mathrm{diag}[\mathrm{bAut}(F)]_{F\in\mathcal{S}}roman_bAut = roman_diag [ roman_bAut ( italic_F ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are |𝒮|×|𝒮|𝒮𝒮|\mathcal{S}|\times|\mathcal{S}|| caligraphic_S | × | caligraphic_S | matrices. Since one can easily show that the binary relation ≼precedes-or-equals\preccurlyeq≼ on 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S defined by F≼F′⇔bInHom⁢(F,F′)≠0⇔precedes-or-equals𝐹superscript𝐹′bInHom𝐹superscript𝐹′0F\preccurlyeq F^{\prime}\Leftrightarrow\mathrm{bInHom}(F,F^{\prime})\neq 0italic_F ≼ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⇔ roman_bInHom ( italic_F , italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ 0 is a partial order on 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, there is a proper ordering of graphs in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S that makes bInHombInHom\mathrm{bInHom}roman_bInHom an upper triangular matrix whose diagonal entries are all non-zero. Furthermore, every diagonal entry of bAut−1superscriptbAut1\mathrm{bAut}^{-1}roman_bAut start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is non-zero. We thus assert that bInHom⋅bAut−1⋅bInHomsuperscriptbAut1\mathrm{bInHom}\cdot\mathrm{bAut}^{-1}roman_bInHom ⋅ roman_bAut start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a full-rank matrix. Hence, given G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G with bIsoHomG≠bIsoHomHsubscriptbIsoHom𝐺subscriptbIsoHom𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}_{G}\neq\mathrm{bIsoHom}_{H}roman_bIsoHom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ roman_bIsoHom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have HomG≠HomHsubscriptHom𝐺subscriptHom𝐻\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\neq\mathrm{Hom}_{H}roman_Hom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ roman_Hom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since we already have bIsoHomG≠bIsoHomHsubscriptbIsoHom𝐺subscriptbIsoHom𝐻\mathrm{bIsoHom}_{G}\neq\mathrm{bIsoHom}_{H}roman_bIsoHom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ roman_bIsoHom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Lemma C.7, we finally arrive at the desired result that HomG≠HomHsubscriptHom𝐺subscriptHom𝐻\mathrm{Hom}_{G}\neq\mathrm{Hom}_{H}roman_Hom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ roman_Hom start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, or that ∃F∈𝒮𝐹𝒮\exists F\in\mathcal{S}∃ italic_F ∈ caligraphic_S, Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ).

(b) ⇒bold-⇒\bm{\Rightarrow}bold_⇒ (a). We prove by giving a winning strategy for Spoiler. Before our proof, we have to introduce some concepts associated with the Cops-Robber game.

Definition C.9.

Let F∈𝒢𝐹𝒢F\in\mathcal{G}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_G and 𝐮=(u1,…,uk)∈𝒱Fk𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐹𝑘\mathbf{u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{F}^{k}bold_u = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Assume that {C1,…,CK}subscript𝐶1…subscript𝐶𝐾\{C_{1},\ldots,C_{K}\}{ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is the complete set of different CCEs of F𝐹Fitalic_F induced by A={u1,…,uk}𝐴subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑘A=\{u_{1},\ldots,u_{k}\}italic_A = { italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Namely, we require Ci∩Cj=∅subscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐶𝑗C_{i}\cap C_{j}=\varnothingitalic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∩ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∅ for any 1⩽i<j⩽K1𝑖𝑗𝐾1\leqslant i<j\leqslant K1 ⩽ italic_i < italic_j ⩽ italic_K, and ⋃i=1KCi=ℰFsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝐶𝑖subscriptℰ𝐹\bigcup_{i=1}^{K}C_{i}=\mathcal{E}_{F}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
(i) Boundary nodes. The set

ℬi={u∈A:∃e1∈Ci⁢ and ⁢e2∈Cj⁢ with ⁢i≠j,e1⁢ and ⁢e2⁢ have ⁢u⁢ as their common end}subscriptℬ𝑖conditional-set𝑢𝐴formulae-sequencesubscript𝑒1subscript𝐶𝑖 and subscript𝑒2subscript𝐶𝑗 with 𝑖𝑗subscript𝑒1 and subscript𝑒2 have 𝑢 as their common end\displaystyle\mathcal{B}_{i}=\{u\in A:\exists e_{1}\in C_{i}\text{ and }e_{2}% \in C_{j}\text{ with }i\neq j,e_{1}\text{ and }e_{2}\text{ have }u\text{ as % their common end}\}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_u ∈ italic_A : ∃ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with italic_i ≠ italic_j , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have italic_u as their common end } (64)

is called the set of boundary nodes of Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
(ii) Internal nodes. The set

ℐi={u∈A:∃e∈Ci,e⁢ has ⁢u⁢ as one of its ends}−ℬisubscriptℐ𝑖conditional-set𝑢𝐴𝑒subscript𝐶𝑖𝑒 has 𝑢 as one of its endssubscriptℬ𝑖\displaystyle\mathcal{I}_{i}=\{u\in A:\exists e\in C_{i},e\text{ has }u\text{ % as one of its ends}\}-\mathcal{B}_{i}caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_u ∈ italic_A : ∃ italic_e ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e has italic_u as one of its ends } - caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (65)

is called the set of internal nodes of Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The following lemma is quite straightforward, but will be useful for our proof.

Lemma C.10.

Keep all assumptions in Definition C.9. Further let G∈𝒢𝐺𝒢G\in\mathcal{G}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_G and 𝐯=(v1,…,vk)∈𝒱Gk𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒱𝐺𝑘\mathbf{v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{k})\in\mathcal{V}_{G}^{k}bold_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If ℬi∪ℐi={uci,1,…,uci,ni}subscriptℬ𝑖subscriptℐ𝑖subscript𝑢subscript𝑐𝑖1…subscript𝑢subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\mathcal{B}_{i}\cup\mathcal{I}_{i}=\{u_{c_{i,1}},\ldots,u_{c_{i,n_{i}}}\}caligraphic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ caligraphic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for i∈[K]𝑖delimited-[]𝐾i\in[K]italic_i ∈ [ italic_K ], with 1⩽ci,1<⋯<ci,ni⩽k1subscript𝑐𝑖1⋯subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑘1\leqslant c_{i,1}<\cdots<c_{i,n_{i}}\leqslant k1 ⩽ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ⋯ < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩽ italic_k, we define the operator 𝐛isubscript𝐛𝑖\mathbf{b}_{i}bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT {G}^{n_{i}}bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v ) = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … ,
