italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have

Hom⁢(F𝐮,G𝐯)=∏i=1KHom⁢(Ci𝐛i⁢(𝐮),G𝐛i⁢(𝐯)).Homsuperscript𝐹𝐮superscript𝐺𝐯superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝐾Homsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐛𝑖𝐮superscript𝐺subscript𝐛𝑖𝐯\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(F^{\mathbf{u}},G^{\mathbf{v}})=\prod_{i=1}^{K}% \mathrm{Hom}(C_{i}^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{u})},G^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{v})}).roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_v end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (66)

With a slight abuse of notation, in equation (66) we use Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to mean the subgraph of F𝐹Fitalic_F edge-induced by edges in Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In the following, we assume that Cops have a winning strategy for the Cops-Robber game on F∈𝒢𝐹𝒢F\in\mathcal{G}italic_F ∈ caligraphic_G. The case is the worst for Cops if no internal nodes become unoccupied in any unguarding move. Actually, if Cops have a winning strategy such that they first put a pebble p𝑝pitalic_p on u𝑢uitalic_u, and u𝑢uitalic_u remains internal until u𝑢uitalic_u becomes unoccupied again in an unguarding move, then Cops can choose to put p𝑝pitalic_p at an alternative boundary node (already occupied by a pebble) and still win. Therefore, we always assume that the aforementioned condition holds.

Let Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ), for some G,H∈𝒢𝐺𝐻𝒢G,H\in\mathcal{G}italic_G , italic_H ∈ caligraphic_G. We will state Spoiler’s winning strategy for the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H. Briefly speaking, Cops will play the role of an oracle that Spoiler should consult before taking each move.

Without loss of generality, we assume that F𝐹Fitalic_F is connected. Otherwise, the fact that Cops win the Cops-Robber game on F𝐹Fitalic_F implies that they must win on each connected component of F𝐹Fitalic_F separately. Moreover, Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ) implies that at least one connected component F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of F𝐹Fitalic_F satisfies Hom⁢(F′,G)≠Hom⁢(F′,H)Homsuperscript𝐹′𝐺Homsuperscript𝐹′𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F^{\prime},G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F^{\prime},H)roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ). Then we can apply the proof on F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Assume that for the first guarding move of the initialization round, Cops should put pebbles p1,…,pi1subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖1p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at 𝐮1=Δ⁢𝐮1=(u1,…,ui1)∈ℛ1⁢(F)subscript𝐮1Δsubscript𝐮1subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢subscript𝑖1subscriptℛ1𝐹\mathbf{u}_{1}=\Delta\mathbf{u}_{1}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{i_{1}})\in\mathcal{R}_{1}% (F)bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_F ). Since ℛ⁢(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot)caligraphic_R ( ⋅ ) is closed under homomorphisms, every homomorphism from F𝐹Fitalic_F to G𝐺Gitalic_G (or H𝐻Hitalic_H) should map 𝐮1subscript𝐮1\mathbf{u}_{1}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to some 𝐯1∈ℛ1⁢(G)subscript𝐯1subscriptℛ1𝐺\mathbf{v}_{1}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) (or 𝐰1∈ℛ1⁢(H)subscript𝐰1subscriptℛ1𝐻\mathbf{w}_{1}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H )). The fact that Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ) implies that if there exists a bijection f:ℛ1⁢(G)→ℛ1⁢(H):𝑓→subscriptℛ1𝐺subscriptℛ1𝐻f:\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)\rightarrow\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)italic_f : caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) → caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ), then we can find 𝐯1∈ℛ1⁢(G)subscript𝐯1subscriptℛ1𝐺\mathbf{v}_{1}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) and 𝐰1=f⁢(𝐯1)∈ℛ1⁢(H)subscript𝐰1𝑓subscript𝐯1subscriptℛ1𝐻\mathbf{w}_{1}=f(\mathbf{v}_{1})\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ) such that

Hom⁢(F𝐮1,G𝐯1)≠Hom⁢(F𝐮1,H𝐰1).Homsuperscript𝐹subscript𝐮1superscript𝐺subscript𝐯1Homsuperscript𝐹subscript𝐮1superscript𝐻subscript𝐰1\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(F^{\mathbf{u}_{1}},G^{\mathbf{v}_{1}})\neq\mathrm{% Hom}(F^{\mathbf{u}_{1}},H^{\mathbf{w}_{1}}).roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (67)

Now let us consider Spoiler’s strategy for the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H. Notice that Duplicator either fails to choose a bijection f:ℛ1⁢(G)→ℛ1⁢(H):𝑓→subscriptℛ1𝐺subscriptℛ1𝐻f:\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)\rightarrow\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)italic_f : caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) → caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ) for the first putting move of the initialization round, or has to choose f𝑓fitalic_f such that equation (67) holds. If the former is the case, Spoiler already wins. Otherwise, we let Spoiler put pebbles p1,…,pi1subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖1p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at 𝐯1∈ℛ1⁢(G)subscript𝐯1subscriptℛ1𝐺\mathbf{v}_{1}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(G)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) that makes (67) hold, and Duplicator then puts pebbles q1,…,qi1subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞subscript𝑖1q_{1},\ldots,q_{i_{1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at 𝐰1∈ℛ1⁢(H)subscript𝐰1subscriptℛ1𝐻\mathbf{w}_{1}\in\mathcal{R}_{1}(H)bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ). By following the above strategy, Spoiler can maintain equation (67) at the end of the first putting move of the initialization round, if he has not yet won at that time.

To proceed, let us further assume that the set of nodes {u1,…,ui1}subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢subscript𝑖1\{u_{1},\ldots,u_{i_{1}}\}{ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } splits F𝐹Fitalic_F into K1(0)superscriptsubscript𝐾10K_{1}^{(0)}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT CCEs, denoted as C1,…,CK1(0)subscript𝐶1…subscript𝐶superscriptsubscript𝐾10C_{1},\ldots,C_{K_{1}^{(0)}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Using Lemma C.10, we can rewrite equation (67) as

∏i=1K1(0)Hom⁢(Ci𝐛i⁢(𝐮1),G𝐛i⁢(𝐯1))≠∏i=1K1(0)Hom⁢(Ci𝐛i⁢(𝐮1),H𝐛i⁢(𝐰1)),superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝐾10Homsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐮1superscript𝐺subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐯1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝐾10Homsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐮1superscript𝐻subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐰1\displaystyle\prod_{i=1}^{K_{1}^{(0)}}\mathrm{Hom}(C_{i}^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(% \mathbf{u}_{1})},G^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{v}_{1})})\neq\prod_{i=1}^{K_{1}^{(0% )}}\mathrm{Hom}(C_{i}^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{u}_{1})},H^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(% \mathbf{w}_{1})}),∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (68)

which further implies ∃i∈[K1(0)]𝑖delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐾10\exists i\in[K_{1}^{(0)}]∃ italic_i ∈ [ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], such that

Hom⁢(Ci𝐛i⁢(𝐮1),G𝐛i⁢(𝐯1))≠Hom⁢(Ci𝐛i⁢(𝐮1),H𝐛i⁢(𝐰1)).Homsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐮1superscript𝐺subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐯1Homsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐮1superscript𝐻subscript𝐛𝑖subscript𝐰1\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(C_{i}^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{u}_{1})},G^{\mathbf{b}% _{i}(\mathbf{v}_{1})})\neq\mathrm{Hom}(C_{i}^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{u}_{1})},% H^{\mathbf{b}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{1})}).roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (69)

One can naturally see Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the CCE chosen by Robber in the first guarding move of the initialization round, as he plays the Cops-Robber game. Now, there are two cases. For the first case, Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT already contains only one edge whose both ends are occupied by pebbles, then equation (69) directly implies that 𝐯1subscript𝐯1\mathbf{v}_{1}bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐰1subscript𝐰1\mathbf{w}_{1}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have different isomorphism types. Therefore, Spoiler already wins. Otherwise, we are sure that whatever Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i∈[K1(0)]𝑖delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐾10i\in[K_{1}^{(0)}]italic_i ∈ [ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]) chosen by Robber, Cops have a way to respond properly, by choosing a corresponding Δ⁢𝐮2∈ℛ2⁢(F)\𝐮1Δsubscript𝐮2\subscriptℛ2𝐹subscript𝐮1\Delta\mathbf{u}_{2}\in\mathcal{R}_{2}(F)\backslash\mathbf{u}_{1}roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_F ) \ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since ℛ⁢(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot)caligraphic_R ( ⋅ ) is closed under homomorphisms, any homomorphism from F𝐹Fitalic_F to G𝐺Gitalic_G (or H𝐻Hitalic_H) should map 𝐮2=(𝐮1,Δ⁢𝐮2)subscript𝐮2subscript𝐮1Δsubscript𝐮2\mathbf{u}_{2}=(\mathbf{u}_{1},\Delta\mathbf{u}_{2})bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to some 𝐯2∈ℛ2⁢(G)subscript𝐯2subscriptℛ2𝐺\mathbf{v}_{2}\in\mathcal{R}_{2}(G)bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) (or some 𝐰2∈ℛ2⁢(H)subscript𝐰2subscriptℛ2𝐻\mathbf{w}_{2}\in\mathcal{R}_{2}(H)bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H )). Therefore, we can repeat the above procedure to give Spoiler’s strategy for the second (and further the n𝑛nitalic_n-th, with 2⩽n⩽N2𝑛𝑁2\leqslant n\leqslant N2 ⩽ italic_n ⩽ italic_N) putting move of the initialization round.

Let 1⩽n⩽N1𝑛𝑁1\leqslant n\leqslant N1 ⩽ italic_n ⩽ italic_N. Assume that after the (n−1)𝑛1(n-1)( italic_n - 1 )-th putting move of the initialization round, neither Duplicator (in the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game) nor Robber (in the Cops-Robber game) has lost. Moreover, we assume that Spoiler can maintain

Hom⁢(C𝐛⁢(𝐮n−1),G𝐛⁢(𝐯n−1))≠Hom⁢(C𝐛⁢(𝐮n−1),H𝐛⁢(𝐰n−1)),Homsuperscript𝐶𝐛subscript𝐮𝑛1superscript𝐺𝐛subscript𝐯𝑛1Homsuperscript𝐶𝐛subscript𝐮𝑛1superscript𝐻𝐛subscript𝐰𝑛1\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(C^{\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{u}_{n-1})},G^{\mathbf{b}(% \mathbf{v}_{n-1})})\neq\mathrm{Hom}(C^{\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{u}_{n-1})},H^{% \mathbf{b}(\mathbf{w}_{n-1})}),roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (70)

where 𝐮n−1subscript𝐮𝑛1\mathbf{u}_{n-1}bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the in−1subscript𝑖𝑛1i_{n-1}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-tuple occupied by pebbles on F𝐹Fitalic_F, and C𝐶Citalic_C is the CCE held by Robber, both at the end of the (n−1)𝑛1(n-1)( italic_n - 1 )-th guarding move of the initialization round; 𝐯n−1subscript𝐯𝑛1\mathbf{v}_{n-1}bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐰n−1subscript𝐰𝑛1\mathbf{w}_{n-1}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the tuples occupied by pebbles p1,…,pin−1subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝subscript𝑖𝑛1p_{1},\ldots,p_{i_{n-1}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (on G𝐺Gitalic_G) and q1,…,qin−1subscript𝑞1…subscript𝑞subscript𝑖𝑛1q_{1},\ldots,q_{i_{n-1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (on H𝐻Hitalic_H), at the end of the (n−1)𝑛1(n-1)( italic_n - 1 )-th putting move of the initialization round; 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b}bold_b is the operator corresponding to C𝐶Citalic_C, as defined in Lemma C.10. Notice that equation (70) goes back to Hom⁢(F,G)≠Hom⁢(F,H)Hom𝐹𝐺Hom𝐹𝐻\mathrm{Hom}(F,G)\neq\mathrm{Hom}(F,H)roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_G ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_F , italic_H ) when n=1𝑛1n=1italic_n = 1, or to (69) when n=2𝑛2n=2italic_n = 2. Using a completely analogous argument to the case of n=1𝑛1n=1italic_n = 1, we can show that Spoiler either wins in the n𝑛nitalic_n-th putting move of the initialization round, or can maintain that

Hom⁢(C𝐛⁢(𝐮n),G𝐛⁢(𝐯n))≠Hom⁢(C𝐛⁢(𝐮n),H𝐛⁢(𝐰n)),Homsuperscript𝐶𝐛subscript𝐮𝑛superscript𝐺𝐛subscript𝐯𝑛Homsuperscript𝐶𝐛subscript𝐮𝑛superscript𝐻𝐛subscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(C^{\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{u}_{n})},G^{\mathbf{b}(\mathbf% {v}_{n})})\neq\mathrm{Hom}(C^{\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{u}_{n})},H^{\mathbf{b}(% \mathbf{w}_{n})}),roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (71)

after the n𝑛nitalic_n-th putting move, where the notations are similar to above except that we are now considering the n𝑛nitalic_n-th putting/guarding move. Similar arguments apply to the putting moves of the update rounds.

What we only need to take care of is the removing moves. Assume that after the M𝑀Mitalic_M-th putting move of some update round, holds

Hom⁢(C𝐛⁢((𝐮N,𝐮M′)),G𝐛⁢((𝐯N,𝐯M′)))≠Hom⁢(C𝐛⁢((𝐮N,𝐮M′)),H𝐛⁢((𝐰N,𝐰M′))).Homsuperscript𝐶𝐛subscript𝐮𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑀superscript𝐺𝐛subscript𝐯𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑀Homsuperscript𝐶𝐛subscript𝐮𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑀superscript𝐻𝐛subscript𝐰𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑀\displaystyle\mathrm{Hom}(C^{\mathbf{b}((\mathbf{u}_{N},\mathbf{u}^{\prime}_{M% }))},G^{\mathbf{b}((\mathbf{v}_{N},\mathbf{v}^{\prime}_{M}))})\neq\mathrm{Hom}% (C^{\mathbf{b}((\mathbf{u}_{N},\mathbf{u}^{\prime}_{M}))},H^{\mathbf{b}((% \mathbf{w}_{N},\mathbf{w}^{\prime}_{M}))}).roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( ( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≠ roman_Hom ( italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b ( ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (72)

Now Spoiler must choose some r1(c),…,rk(c)superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑐…superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑐r_{1}^{(c)},\ldots,r_{k}^{(c)}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with c∈[C]𝑐delimited-[]𝐶c\in[C]italic_c ∈ [ italic_C ], such that only the tuples (𝐯N)c⁢(𝐯M′)subscriptsubscript𝐯𝑁𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐯′𝑀(\mathbf{v}_{N})_{c}(\mathbf{v}^{\prime}_{M})( bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (𝐰N)c⁢(𝐰M′)subscriptsubscript𝐰𝑁𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐰′𝑀(\mathbf{w}_{N})_{c}(\mathbf{w}^{\prime}_{M})( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) will remain occupied on G𝐺Gitalic_G and H𝐻Hitalic_H, respectively. The proof cannot move on to the next update round unless we have

𝐛⁢((𝐮N,𝐮M′))=𝐛⁢((𝐮N)c⁢(𝐮M′)).𝐛subscript𝐮𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑀𝐛subscriptsubscript𝐮𝑁𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐮′𝑀\displaystyle\mathbf{b}((\mathbf{u}_{N},\mathbf{u}^{\prime}_{M}))=\mathbf{b}((% \mathbf{u}_{N})_{c}(\mathbf{u}^{\prime}_{M})).bold_b ( ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = bold_b ( ( bold_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) . (73)

Namely, we require that the union of boundary and internal nodes of C𝐶Citalic_C remains unchanged after the corresponding unguarding move. Since Cops can win the Cops-Robber game on F𝐹Fitalic_F, Cops can keep C𝐶Citalic_C itself unchanged after the unguarding move. Therefore, the boundary nodes of C𝐶Citalic_C remain unchanged. Thanks to our assumption that no internal nodes become unoccupied after the unguarding move, we assert that the internal nodes of C𝐶Citalic_C also remain unchanged. We thus see (73) holds. So far, we have made the proof. ∎

Report Github Issue
Generated by L A T E xml

Instructions for reporting errors

We are continuing to improve HTML versions of papers, and your feedback helps enhance accessibility and mobile support. To report errors in the HTML that will help us improve conversion and rendering, choose any of the methods listed below:

  • Click the "Report Issue" button.
  • Open a report feedback form via keyboard, use "Ctrl + ?".
  • Make a text selection and click the "Report Issue for Selection" button near your cursor.
  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
